Posts.Title: Anyone know the difference between Letrozole and Anastrazole please...

Posts.Content: A very difficult decision. Have you discussed this with your surgeon? He/She must have an opinion and should discuss this with you before you proceed. It may be that they will refuse to do it because it is not diseased. I've heard of women with the faulty gene having this done but if you have been genetically tested and have been given the all clear then jt would be hasty to have this proceedure. Do think long and hard before you make a decision. Best wishes KateG

Please keep posting with any questions you may have... or even if you want to have a rant or scream... no-one will judge you... we are on your side. Best wishes KateG

Posts.Title: Questions ref radiotherapy

Posts.Content: No, not everyone has chemo but every patient and each diagnosis is treated individually. Whilst some patients have a mastectomy and full node clearance, and  whilst others may only have a mastectomy, others again have a wide local incision followed by radiotherapy. It is so difficult - its a bit like "how long is a piece of string?". We have to depend on our medical team to do their best to prescribe the correct treatment for US depending on our individual diagnosis.. Do let us know how you get along. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: At last

Posts.Content: Hi Carol, Did you have a question? The site takes a bit of getting used to so if you want to ask something just reply to this. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: n

Posts.Content: It is a very scary time and those have not heard those dreaded words, 'It's cancer' can't really understand. It's that horrible feeling of being smacked in the mouth - it sends you reeling with disbelief. It does you good to have the occassional good cry  but it is also good to remember how treatments for BC have come on in leaps and bounds. Okay, treatment isn't a walk in the park but you WILL get through it - promise. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Feeling as though the cancer is now real

Posts.Content: I have been fortunate that until my diagnosis with cancer I was very healthy. My visits to my GP were limited to the odd minor ailment and I felt content with the service I received. However, a serious illness sure makes you take your treatment seriously and over the last year I have been in and out of the GP surgery like a fiddler's elbow! I had been a patient at the same practice for 25 years and seen quite a few doctors come and go but the turnover of staff seemed to accelerate of late and on my last few visits I have not been seen by a doctor whose first language is English. I do not have a hearing problem and I am articulate but I was finding it increasingly difficult to communicate my problems or understand their answers. The final straw came just before Christmas when I had spent some time explaining my problem and concluded with the words, "It started about 10 days ago." And the GP replied, "What started about 10 days ago?" Argggh!! I asked a friend to recommend another practice and off I went with my medical card all filled out. It said on the card that was all I needed to do - wrong! I was given a stack of forms to fill in and asked to return with my passport and a utility bill to prove I was who I said I was and where I lived. I returned the following day and handed them in only to be told I was not allowed to register with them as I was already registered with a doctor in the area. I was spitting feathers! My husband was spitting swear words so I dragged him out before things got nasty. My daughter suggested we contact the Primary Care Trust for our area so my husband set about finding what to do and who to contact. I had to write a letter giving all our details (NHS numbers. Existing GP's number, address, etc.) together with a written explanation of WHY we wanted to change doctors. I didn't think I could write "because I want a doctor whose first language is English" for fear of accusations of racial prejudice, so I wrote a vaguely worded letter referring to large turnover of staff lately and sent it off recorded delivery. To my intense relief the PCT replied that we could change practice. My first visit to my new GP was so refreshing - absolutely no communication problems. Wonderful. And worth all the aggro! KateG
Posts.Title: Changing your GP

Posts.Content: I have been taking Tamoxifen for five years but do not believe it in itself causes depression. I believe (rightly or wrongly) that after the really 'active' period of treatment (slash poison and burn) and we are shipped off with hormone drugs as our only life-boat and the reality of the trauma we have suffered and survived comes home, it is only then that the realisation of what has happened hits us like the proverbial ton on bricks! I am not denying how you feel, simply offering an explanation and the assurance that these feelings will pass. Best wishes KateG.

Posts.Title: Second Lump five weeks after lumpectomy - anyone else?

Posts.Content: I would strongly recommend changing hospitals to cut down travel time; radiotherapy can increase fatigue which builds up over time. The first couple of weeks I was fine but the tiredness gradually increased and continued after the treatment ended. It really helps if you increase your fluid intake and this means water not gin and tonic lol! Good luck with the rest of your treatment. KateG
Posts.Title: change hospitals for radiotherapy?

Posts.Content: You may have a 'SEROMA' which is a collection of fluid a bit like the clear yellow liquid you have after a grazed knee. I had one which needed to be drained several times. First time about  half a pint, the second - a third of a pint, and the third time a quarter of a pint. When I first went back to the oncology team they told me it would settle with time... but it didn't! I had to push for it to be drained and the relief when it was drained was wonderful. Beloved husband saw it being drained and, astounded at the amount of fluid draining into the bottle, went quite pale! Don't be palmed off - make a fuss! KateG
Posts.Title: Infection after Lumpectomy& SNB

Posts.Content: I had two lumpectomies and a full node clearance in January 2007. I have a mixture of numbness and pain mainly in my arm and armpit. I understand that the pain is due to the nerves trying to knit back together. Some days I have no pain, whilst on others I feel as if I am being stabbed in the armpit. Whenever I have mentioned it to my oncologist he sort of shrugs and says it is normal. However, if I was in such constant pain as you, I'd be inclined to make more of a fuss. Incidentally, I had 25 sessions of radiotherapy. Hope this helps. Best wishes KateG

Posts.Title: What to do ... my mother in law

Posts.Content: I'm not sure about any 'rules' covering whether or not you can go on holiday but my radiotherapy was delayed because I could not move my arm high enough above my head. I had an axillary clearance which left my arm sore and I needed to do excercises to  increase movement. My  radiotherapy Consultant didn't seem concerned by delaying treatment. Do discuss this with your medics. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: holiday!

Posts.Content: Oh sweetheart - your poor body has gone through an awful trauma and whilst I can understand your impatience to get 'back to normal'  but it will take time to heal. My surgery was nowhere as radical as yours (two lumpectomies and axillary clearance) but because they cut through so many nerves to remove all the lymph nodes, I still have (four years post surgery) some areas of numbness and also occassional twinges. You WILL feel better - especially if you keep up the excercises to regain better  flexibilty . Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: How long of a recovery time from op ????

Posts.Content: "Taking it one day at a time" is excellent advice, and yes, there will be some low days and some up days but this journey will come to an end. It is a journey but you WILL come through; rates of survival of BC are BRILLIANT. Please come to the site when you need to let off steam because we will be here to listen. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Taking it one day at a time

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed in the September/October but my surgery was delayed until the following January/February because I had Shingles over the breast and the surgeon was concerned about (more) nerve damage. The surgery originally planned was not neccessary as the Femara ( one trade name for Letrozole) I was taking as stop-gap treatment shrank the tumour so much it meant the surgery was not so radical. I admit I was 'wanting the damn thing out NOW!' and was really worried by the delay in surgery but, in the long run it did me a BIG favour. Three cheers for Femara! Best wishes KateG

Posts.Content: The medical staff have not shown you any respect! You should be able to cover yourself until you are on the radiotherapy table. There's a lot of moving 'this way, and that' on the radiotherapy table until they can fix the 'rays' on exactly where is required. There will come a time, although you may not believe it right this minute, when you will look at your tiny dot tattto with a badge of honour - something to prove you have 'kicked cancer's butt'! Best wishes, KateG

Posts.Title: Breast cancer at a young age- second time

Posts.Content: Every patient has an individual diagnosis. I had one WLE with an axillary clearance, followed by another surgery to find clear margins. This was followed by radiotherapy and five + years of hormone therapy (Letrozole then Tamoxifen) and am now 6 years post diagnosis and still KICKING  cancer's butt! The prognosis of BC patients is 85% of patients survive for at least five years. Survival rates are BRILLIANT! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Further surgery for 'wider margins' and more lymph nodes to be re

Posts.Content: It is sooooo scary when you are first diagnosed - I remember I felt like I'd been hit by a ten-ton truck but once you have a treatment plan in place you will be feeling more in control again. Treatments for BC have advanced so much and recovery rates are brilliant. I'm five years past treatment and fighting fit. Posts.Title: Has anyone else had experience of adenoid cystic carcinoma of the...

Posts.Content: The pain in your axilla may not be down to sun-burn - I had my axillary clearance over five years ago but sometimes still have occasional stabbing pain in that area. I am not medically qualified but as I understand it, sunbathing the area which received radiotherapy may be more prone to skin damage. Without sounding 'preaching' ... I suppose it is all things in moderation. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: sunbathing after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: OMG! It is a bit like offering someone on a diet a deep-fried Mars Bar! "I WANT ONE BUT I CAN'T HAVE ONE ..... ARGH! " Sorry, not to make light of this situation, but  hey?  I'm so glad the hairdresser is going to keep to his word and when it is time - ENJOY! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: not sure whether to laugh or cry

Posts.Content: I too had a seroma. I had it drained quite a few times - each time it was a little less (half a pint, third of a pint, quarter of a pint... and so on). It eventually settled down on its own. Don't suffer in silence! Good luck, KateG
Posts.Title: Post op fluid advice please

Posts.Content: Ladycaptain - the moderators on this site strongly reccommend that you do not post personal details on the site because, unfortunately, there are some people who abuse the site (trolls and fakes). They suggest you ask a person to 'be a friend' and then exchange personal messages which are private. I know it is a horrible thought that people abuse the site but those of us who have been members of Mac  for some time have witnessed this many times and so it is only fair to warn you and suggest you take down this personal information for your own protection. I am not suggesting for a minute that the person who started this thread is a fraud but postings are open to be read by members of the public not all of whom are genuine. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Triple Postive Result

Posts.Content: I don't know what happened to my original reply - it didn't show what I thought I'd posted. Gremlins in the works no doubt! I had a lumpectomy and a full axillary clearance but I had to go back for further surgery because I too did not have clear margins. The second operation was a piece of cake compared to the first and I was fighting fit the next day so I trust it will be the same for you. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Nipple Duct Excision - would appreciate your experiences on this one...

Posts.Content: People who haven't experienced this horrible disease regularly put their foot in it! A neighbour met me in the supermarket shortly after my diagnosis and came out with a classic: "So how long have you got?" Charming! I think it is simply that they don't know what to say and they trip over their words. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: so annoyed with crass comments

Posts.Content: I think everyone feels the same way when active treatment is over - we had this high level of involement in hospital appointments and treatment and then suddenly.... "Off you go - on your own". It is so scary but it DOES get easier - honest! I found that they slowly 'weaned' me away from treatment - six-weekly appointments went to three-monthly, to six-monthly to annually. It is nice to have some contact with the hospital but I also found help from an informal support group. I belong to another site www.breastcancercare.co and someoneon the site posted an appeal and asked if anyone in her area was interested in a meet-up. Eight of us, all treated at the same hospital, get together for a lunch about every two months and it is so good to talk to other women who have gone through similar experiences. It is surprising how much fun we have and how much laughter happens at these lunches. Do try and contact others in your area - it will help. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: after treatment

Posts.Content: I'm a lot older than you but have raised a family so I know how hard it must be for you to cope. Do you have relatives or friends who could help ease the burden? Don't be too proud to ask for help - I was so full of 'I'm coping' crap when I really needed help. People WANT to help, they WANT to feel useful so say 'Yes, thanks' to any offer. Your children are too young to understand what their mummy is going through so you won't be able to reason with even the three-year-old. You might explain in simple terms that 'Mummy has a bad tummy-ache, so please can you let mummy rest?' but don't hold your breath that a truce has been drawn! Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Coping with cancer treatment AND young kids!

Posts.Content: Our lives have been turned upside-down and inside-out by the diagnosis and treatment and so it comes as no surprise that we never feel the same again. What we need to accept is that there is now the 'New Normal'. After bowling along through life thinking we're invincible it comes as one hell of a shock to realise we are vulnerable and mortal. t takes a while for this to sink into our conciousnessI I'm nearing the fifth anniversary of my diagnosis and am now accepting my 'New Normal'. It will become easier as time passes for you. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: out of control and scared

Posts.Content: I have battled with my weight all my life, on one diet I halved my body weight and everyone said I looked awful! I thought I looked fab lol! I have been on a, 'sensible eating regime' since my diagnosis and it was taken me five years to loose 3 stone. I don't know what Tamoxifen does to the metabolism and I will be interested to see how ceasing Tamoxifen in March (end of my five-year sentence lol!) will affect the speed at which I lose weight. Everyone seems to be raving about the 'fasting two days a week  - 500 cals, then eating normally the other five. The days of fasting not to be consecutive. Not sure I could trust myself on non-fasting days - probably scoff all the buns! Good luck to you all. KateG
Posts.Title: how to lose weight on tamoxifen

Posts.Content: I was a 30 a day sinner and tried to give up soooooo many times. The final time I 'gave up' started with a stinker of a cold which put me off smoking so I grabbed the chance of using patches which I stuck with before changing to inhalators. The inhalators gave me something to 'play' with ... the something to twiddle my fingers. I know it is really hard and even now, fifteen years down the line I still follow smokers down the street hoping to get a whiff of second-hand smoke. Lots of positive vibes coming your way... KateG
Posts.Title: BC and smoking

Posts.Content: That is really good news! Let's hope it continues to kick the lump into touch! Best wishes, KateG

Posts.Title: Bra Trouble After WLE

Posts.Content: Hello Mandi, Sorry that you have needed to join us but you will find help and support from all the wonderful women here on this site. It does sound as if you've been through a rough time and are so entitled to be fed up but please feel free to have a good old moan because no-one here will judge. I notice you have not filled in your Profile Page but please do so because the more we know about your illness and treatment the better we can help and advise. You may find it helpful to talk to one of the nurses/advisors on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Im New

Posts.Content: So sorry you are feeling so low.... although it is natural, so don't beat yourself up! I didn't have chemo but do belong to a BC support group and know many women who have had chemo, and whilst it is not easy, it is 'do-able'. You may feel very alone but you are not - you have the support of every woman here who has experienced what is happening to you at the moment. Big cyber hugs, KateG
Posts.Title: Day 3 after 2nd chemo treatment....

Posts.Content: My many dogs, over a period of forty years, have exited this life with dignity... whilst we are not afforded the same privilage. Whoops! I'm on my soapbox again! KateG
Posts.Title: Paget's Disease

Posts.Content: Oh dear Rosie, it does seem you have a lot on your plate. Yes, radiotherapy can make you feel very tired but I never had a problem lifting a kettle! However, she does need to get on with the treatment and the sooner it starts the better the outcome. Please encourage your mum to get on with the treatment and take watever is offered. I'm sure it will help you (and your mum) to talk to one of the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: mum has stage 3 grade 3... what does it mean??!

Posts.Content: Some patients with other conditions are often treated only with drugs such as Tamoxifen or Letrozole. This will not cure the disease but certainly slow down its progress. Do ask the team looking after your mum if this form of treatment will be suitable. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Paget's Disease

Posts.Content: Don't worry - "The Shower will wash all his troubles away" lol! KateG
Posts.Title: TRivial BUT..............

Posts.Content: Fingers, toes, and legs crossed for you - might have trouble walking but wishing you have good results! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: OMG Sentinel Biopsy results tomorrow

Posts.Content: Your poor body has been through the mill and you need time to regain your strength so I would certainly take more time off and ask HR for a phased return plan. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Going back to work

Posts.Content: Forgot to say but the wonderful nurses here on this site can point you in the direction of experts in employment law. You must know your employment rights when dealing with a less than sympathetic employer. Do give them a call on freephone 0808 808 0000 - Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Going back to work

Posts.Content: It may be lymphedema or a seroma. Doing your exercises is good but it might be worthwhile having a word with your breast nurse or your GP in case it is lymphedema  and they can refer you to a suitably trained nurse who can offer treatmeant. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: swelling of arm

Posts.Content: Oh that is a crock of poo! I don't know the answer but suggest you give one of the nurses here a ring on Monday. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: PMS and Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: What a lovely post! Yes, this is a wonderful support network and so many brave women are holding each other up through horrible times. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: To Infinity & Beyyyyyyond !!

Posts.Content: Sorry ladies, but it does take a while for the effects of radiotherapy to work their way out of the system. Drink lots of water, rest when you are tired... go with the flow and don't beat yourselves up. It does get better - honest! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Wiped out after Rads !!

Posts.Content: If you don't have a reply here might I suggest you join the Breast Cancer Care site. bcc.org.uk where you will more probably have a reply. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Anyone had ovaries removed as a precaution?

Posts.Content: Wow, this sounds horrible and I can't say I have heard of this side-effect before. I strongly recommend that you speak to a medical professional about this problem and rattle cages until you get a satisfactory explanation. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Sick for almost a year

Posts.Content: I had radiotherapy treatment on my left side and the Consultant Radiotherapy Oncologist(The horse's mouth!) said that in past times, when they couldn't control and aim the radiotherapy rays there was a possibility of damage to the heart but that things have improved so much it is no longer a danger. She pointed out that it was still written on the consent form that there was a possibility of heart damage but that the form was seriously out of date. Put your mind at rest! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Rarer Side effects of Radiotherapy to chest wall

Posts.Content: In the past I have blamed Tamoxifen for EVERYTHING.... including global warming lol! However, anxiety is not on the list of side-effects. For you to be anxious is perfectly normal - you have been through a rough time, your world has been turned upside-down. You are bound to be stressed but as time passes you will begin to relax. Be kind to yourself. KateG
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and anxiety

Posts.Content: Oh Sweetheart, you are certainly not alone, I certainly felt the same as you do for several weeks after radiotherapy. Your body has been through the wringer and you will need time to recover fully. One tip that helped me was to keep well-hydrated and this means lots of water NOT gin and tonic lol! Be kind to yourself, lay back and get someone to peel you a grape. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Post Radiotherapy exhaustion

Posts.Content: I am not a medic but from what I understand if the patient is post-menopausal and there is no lymph node involvement then the patient has removal of the cancer followed by radiotherapy. Each case is different and you must trust the reccomendation of your oncologist. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Choice of Chemo or Radiotherapy

Posts.Content: I'm sorry, I don't know about any link but I'm sure you will benefit from a chat with one of the nurses here on this site. What they don't know they will always know who to ask - they have a vast library and have all sorts of expertise at their finger-tips. Do call them on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Anastrozole/Thyroxine

Posts.Content: I think this might be too technical for members to reply so I suggest you contact one of our nurses here on this site, They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: tamoxifen and arthritis

Posts.Content: Not quite in the same position; my surgery was delayed and delayed - diagnosis early October then a wait for surgery until January, then another surgery in February. Because of this delay I was put on Letrozole which shrank the tumour so much that the surgery was far less radical than originally planned. Tamoxifen is working in your favour so don't be too down-hearted. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Frustrated and anxious as chemo is delayed

Posts.Content: You have my sympathy because my skin split under my breast - again weeks after radiotherapy finished. The radiology team prescribed a different cream (can't remember the name) plus jellonet and Melolin dressings which do not stick to the skin but absord any weepiness from the wound. It took a few weeks but it did heal eventually. Hope you don't have any more trouble with your skin. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy/Aqueous Cream and damaged skin

Posts.Content: I'm sorry, I can't answer your question but I'm sure the nurses on this site will be able to help. They work 'office hours' but do 'phone them on: 0808 808 0000 - they're really lovely and helpful. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Capsular Contracture

Posts.Content: You can reply to others answers on the same page - just hit the REPLY button under their reply. Hope that is not too confusing! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: anyadvice on lumpy breast

Posts.Content: Of course the final decision is yours but I favour the belt AND braces treatment plan. Even if there is the tiniest chance of some stray cell floating off around your body I would do ANYTHING to prevent it happening. Do take the advice of your oncologist. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Rarer Side effects of Radiotherapy to chest wall

Posts.Content: You poor body has been put through the mangle and it needs time to recover. Radiotherapy does induce tiredness - the proffessionals call it 'fatigue' but that doesn't exactly describe it, it is more akin to being knackered! One thing that helps is to increase your fluid intake - and that means water, not gin lol! It does improve with time but take it easy and be kind to yourself. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Feeling so tired and unwell

Posts.Content: I think this may be one for the helpline? The nurses have all sorts of information at their finger tips and even have a specialist library. So do give them a call on freephone 0808 808 0000 (Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm). Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Hair dye

Posts.Content: You are not alone! I had problems whilst on Letrozole (Femara) - vaginal dryness which led to infections... yuk! It took a lot of courage to bring the subject up with my Consultant but he was sympathetic and changed my prescription to Tamoxifen which allows one to also receive locally applied oestrogen cream which counteracts the dryness and therefore stops the infections. If you want a 'blow-by-blow' answer then click on my picture (avatar) which will lead you to my Profile Page. Once there, click on my 'Blogs' and search for 'NETTLES IN MY KNICKERS'. Do I need say more? Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Side effects from Letrozole

Posts.Content: Oh you poor thing - you're bound to be worried. I have no medical knowledge so can't comment on any of your symptoms and it is a shame I missed your post until now because the Mac help-line is closed until Monday at 9am. If you get time before your appointment on Monday do call one of the nurses here on the site on freephone 0808 808 0000. In the meantime I'm sending you cyber-hugs. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: New Lump in Reconstructed Breast

Posts.Content: I think it would help you to talk to the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm. It is a free line - 0808 808 0000. They are very kind, helpful and honest. Please don't imagine that anyone is 'cutting costs' in your treatment.- you are a young woman, if they want to cut costs don't you think they would get rid of the 'wrinkly's' first? Best wishes, Your 'wrinkly' friend, KateG
Posts.Title: Anyone else been given the following 2 chemos???

Posts.Content: Whoop-de-do! Good news - kicking cancer into touch! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Semi graduate......chemo done, rads done......

Posts.Content: Oh wow! I didn't have an MRI a year post treatment - I only had a mammogram and a physical exam. I have had an MRI because of different health problems and, apart from not being allowed to fidget, it was fine. Some patients ask for a drug to make them relax such as Diazapan  - something which dopes some folk, whilst others (me included) did not notice Anything! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: MRI mammogram

Posts.Content: I had a lymph node clearance at the same time as a lumpectomy - turned out I didn't have any infected nodes so I was a bit peeved lol! The plus side for you is if they don't find any then they won't need to do it unneccesarily. I'm sure they'll give you time to heal at bit more before they do the surgery if it is neccessary. I'll keep everything crossed for you for Tuesday and let us know how you get along. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: lymph node clearance

Posts.Content: I had two dogs whilst I had a treatment and they were both so quiet and kind. Normally they were bouncing off the walls but they seemed to sense I was ill and rather than jumping all over me they would sit by my side and rest a head gently on my lap. The dog who is (as a puppy) my avatar was especially kind to me sadly contracted cancer last year and died aged five last year. I know it sounds stupid but I feel guilty surviving when he had to die. Dogs give us so much unconditional love so I'm sure your dog will forgive you! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: I have just upset the dog

Posts.Content: Hysterical ! KateG
Posts.Title: I Wish I'd Felt Both Of Me Tits - (adapted from Pam Ayers)

Posts.Content: Oh, Helen, you need more support! Do you live alone? Is there a friend who could stay with you for a few days? Do you have a 'Breast Care Nurse' assigned to you by the hospital? Can you easily contact your GP? You need help and you should demand help. Please talk to the nurses here on this site and ask for advice. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Op

Posts.Content: When you say 'early' how early do you mean? Also, why did you stop taking it? I took Letrozole pre surgery, and for a while after and then switched to Tamoxifen - in all I took hormone repressing drugs for nearly six years. At one point my consultant suggested a 'holiday' of a month to see if I felt better without the drugs and told me it would not do harm by giving my body a rest. I stuck with the drug but, in April (when I had 'served my time') I stopped taking them but did not find any appreciable difference in my well-being. I kept taking the drug because I wanted the best possible chance of kicking cancer in the bum! The side-effects of Tamoxifen seemed a small price to pay for a prolonged life.  Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Stopped taking tamoxifen early....

Posts.Content: I have no medical knowledge but as far as I understand it an axillary clearance does not necessarily mean every single node is taken away. It might be that the remaining nodes are reacting - therefore your oncologist's opinion. But, like I said, I have no medical knowledge! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Confused??????

Posts.Content: Good news, Pam. You are bound to worry and it is easy saying, "Don't worry" but we all do lol! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: letrozol and bleeding

Posts.Content: I think we all remember when we were told we have cancer. Like you, I had a family member (my sister) who had died of BC and I expected the same outcome. Treatments have improved so much in recent times and as mistymoley says 85% survive for five years or longer- I am six years post surgery and kicking cancer's butt! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Thought i was going to die

Posts.Content: I've just read your Profile Page - you have been hit with a double whammy! Do you know what further treatment you'll be having? Whatever it is you'll have support from the lovely ladies here. Do keep posting and let us know how you get on. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: After Lumpectomy

Posts.Content: I think all the hormone treatments are responsible for weight gain which is another of the joys of cancer treatment!  It is very hard but it is really down to eat less and move more. I have stuggled with mmy weight all my life so I know how hard it is and wish you every success. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Anastrozole & weight

Posts.Content: I'm so sorry you have had to join us but there are a lot of lovely ladies here on this site to offer help and advice. You can always talk to one of the nurses here on this site - they operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. Posts.Title: Neely diagnosed

Posts.Content: I don't have any medical knowledge but if I had the symptoms you describe I would go to the GP. You might also want to discuss this with one of the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: letrozol and bleeding

Posts.Content: Have you ever heard the saying, "Cancer makes you go deaf"? The word CANCER seems to stop the world turning and it is sooo scary! You need to put your mind at rest so please 'phone the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: should I be worried....waiting for results

Posts.Content: I know it is a daunting time for at the moment but the surgery wasn't as bad as I expected. I'm glad you've got a supportive team taking care of you, it must be reassuring. I'll keep my fingers crossed for you and do tell us how you get along. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: should I be worried....waiting for results

Posts.Content: You certainly find out who your friends are when you have cancer. Some folk have an automatic 'foot-in-mouth' response like the neighbour I met in a supermarket who said, "So how long have you got?" I was gobsmacked to say the least! Nearly five years on and I'm still here and kicking! As for your ex - I'd stick pins in an effigy lol! Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: People's reactions

Posts.Content: This is an appeal to families caring for someone with cancer to remember to tell their friends. This was brought home to me this week when I heard a dear friend had been diagnosed with cancer, had died and the funeral taken place before any of his friends knew. I had known this man for 25 years; we belonged to the same club. He visited my house once every two weeks for a workshop so we were in fairly regular contact. He 'phoned me November to say he wasn't able to come to the workshop for a while as he was having problems with his knees and was going to have a joint replacement operation. I left a 'phone message for him in December, then sent him an email in early January. I 'phoned other friends to ask if anyone had heard from him or anything about him but hit a brick wall. Of course, what I didn't know was the joint pain had turned out to be cancer and he'd been taken into a hospice. I appreciate that families have their own problems and grief with which to deal but a quick flick through their loved one's address book and a 'phone call to a friend (or a Club Secretary) with the news would be appreciated. All this man's friends from the club are saddened that we could not support him with visits, cards or flowers. We are also disappointed that we could not attend his funeral to pay our last respects. KateG
Posts.Title: An appeal to families

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, Thank you for your responses. I agree, modern man seems to compartmentalise relationships: family, work-mates, friends, neighbours and crossovers are rare. I can understand not wanting invasions of visitors when you are feeling rough but true friends would check first. I found great comfort from all the cards people sent - I was amazed how many people I thought of as acquaintances took the time and trouble to send a card. I just wish I could have at least been able to send my friend a card. KateG
Posts.Title: An appeal to families

Posts.Content: Certainly check with your doctor before you use deoderant especially if you are going to have radiotherapy. As to driving - I had an axillary clearance and I found travelling in a car let alone driving was uncomfortable. I found propping my arm up on a big cushion helped both at home and in the car. I started driving after around six weeks and I was so nervous I had to practise by going around the block a few times lol! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Deodrant

Posts.Content: Seconded! It is a wonderful treat at a time when you're feeling low. You can also make a direct request via their website www.lookgoodfeelbetter.org . There is sometimes a waiting list but it is worth the wait. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: 'Look good, feel better' session

Posts.Content: As you are still being treated your first port of call should be your hospital. Mention it to radiotherapy and ask their advice. I know it is easy to say 'don't worry' because we are ALL made parinoid by the diagnosis but remember our breasts are often lumpy and bumpy. Do you have a breast nurse? You should have had one appointed to you immediately after your diagnosis. If you haven't ,then ask again at the hospital. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Pea size lumps in other breast

Posts.Content: Hi Lyndy, I don't think your mum would be upset if you looked through her address book to contact her friends. I'm so sorry her fellow church-goers are not visiting. Can you have a word with the vicar/priest? You sound like a very caring daughter so I'm sure you will do your best for everyone. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: An appeal to families

Posts.Content: Hi Libby, You may be feeling sick and giddy as a reaction to anesthetic. The pain is normal but will improve given time. Unfortunately they may have cut through nerves when removing the lymph node and this will need to heal. As to what questions to ask - I suggest you go to the Cancer Information 'button' on the top left of the page. Search through this for breast cancer and there should be lots of information there. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: New to the Group and Looking for Answers and Advice

Posts.Content: I didn't have chemo but only surgery and radiotherapy... and, even though I was a fit pensioner and leading an active life, there was NO WAY I could have worked through the demands of chemo. PLEASE be kind to yourself... you are not 'Superwoman' (and neither am I lol!) Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Day 7 Am I a softy?

Posts.Content: I know it's a pain to drink water before sleep but honestly, if it helps them surely, getting up in the middle of the night to go to the loo is a small price to pay? I get up to go to the loo but find it easy to get back to sleep. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: low temp

Posts.Content: Thank you for posting this information, I'm sure it will be useful to many members. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Beanie boobie

Posts.Content: Please don't beat yourself up about this because what you're experiencing is perfectly normal. Radiotherapy side-effects continue after treatment for weeks and feeling fatigued is one of the side-effects. It is difficult for others to understand because there are no outward signs, I mean you'd get more sympathy if you had your leg in plaster. Be kind to yourself and take baby steps. I know I thought I should be 'Superwoman' and tried to 'get back to normal' but my body wasn't having any of it! You will get better - honest! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: finished rads 3 weeks ago - fatigue

Posts.Content: Oh, I'm so sorry you are faced with these decisions. It is difficult, but please take the advice of your doctors; they've spent years and years studying and practising medcine - they are the experts. As to whether you should return to New Zealnd... um very difficult... I think you must follow your heart. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed and considering treatment options

Posts.Content: I'm sorry you have this dilemma - I think we would all feel the same way. It is hard to acknowledge the "New Normal" but if you feel happy with your new prosthesis then give it a few weeks before you make decisions about your future. On a slightly lighter note... a friend who was using a prosthesis, lost it whilst preparing a meal for guests so she stuffed a sock into her bra. Her guests arrived and whilst they were enjoying their meal, my friend's dog toddled into the dining room with her prosthesis in its mouth and presented it to her as if it was a 'prize' trophy. Embarrassed smiles.... all around. Big cyber hugs KateG
Posts.Title: New prosthesis

Posts.Content: Glad to know you're feeling so positive. It will be a relief to end treatment but don't be surprised if you also feel a little 'lost'. After the intense period of appointments and treatment to suddenly be on your own can be a bit disconcerting. I hope 2012 will be a better  year for you. KateG
Posts.Title: I've been neglecting to log on

Posts.Content: Oh shame! It sounds like you might be the only one sober and you can feel  all superior lol!. I had to forgo alcohol during a long course of antibiotics and was amazed at how silly my companions were after they'd had a few drinks. Well done for coming so far and good luck with the rads and enjoy your New Year. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: A 'dry' New Year!

Posts.Content: Great news! Always wonderful when someone posts a positive entry. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Feeling upbeat today

Posts.Content: Oh sweetheart - we all have wobbles! One year after diagnosis I was putting away the Christmas Decs and Gloria Gaynor came on the radio singing 'I will survive'. The previous years when I put the decs away, I wasn't sure I'd be around to take them out of their box again and I fell apart. It is a horrible scarey time but, honestly, nothing is as bad as you imagine. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Having a bit of a wobble.......

Posts.Content: Oh Sweetheart, it sounds as if you have been through the mill! I do not have any medical knowledge but do please talk to the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Neuropathy on my feet and hands and exercise

Posts.Content: You sound   well-prepared so the only extra tips I can give you are; walk around when you can and avoid alcohol but keep well-hydrated. And HAVE A LOVELY TIME!! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Long haul travel on Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Oh sweetheart - I'm so sorry but even the loveliest of children can be very hurtful at times. I'm 63 years old and I've had lots of experience with children so please let me reassure you that your son is normal - all kids kick out at their parents and say the most horrible things, it is, unfortunately, all part of growing up.... growing apart... from their parents. You can help him grow emotionally and morally by sitting him down and calmly and quietly talking through what he has said and how it has been so hurtful. You don't have to lay any great 'guilt-trip' on him, simply explain. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: My 9 year old son is so angry with me

Posts.Content: Sorry Rhonda, I'm not familiar with this drug but it seems we all react differently to different drugs. I had Letrozole for several months because I was post-menopausal, but changed to Tamoxifen because Letrozole caused gyne problems. With Tamoxifen I was able to use a locally applied oestrogen cream which sorted the gyne problem. I don't think any of these drugs come without side-effects but .... at least they're kicking cancer's butt! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: clonidine

Posts.Content: I took my dressings off about six days after surgery but it might be as well to check with either your GP or speak to one of the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy plasters

Posts.Title: Surgery results and very relieved!

Posts.Content: Oh Sweetheart, I don't know the answer to this but suggest you speak to one of the nurses here on this site who offer excellent advice. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG

Posts.Title: weight lose - chemo

Posts.Title: Second time around? Results tomorrow

Posts.Content: I think it may be coincidental because it coincided with the end of active treatment. You may be feeling 'abandoned' by your medical team. I think a lot of us experience this feeling of abandonment after the initial rush of; diagnosis and surgery, chemo and/or radiotherapy when we are suddenly set adrift with only a daily pill as a life-raft. Then, after five years they take that little pill away and we are cast off the life-raft. Yes, it is scary, but as long as you keep vigilant about examining yourself and turning up for your three-yearly mammograms, you are as likely as the next person to develop breast cancer.You are FREE! Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: after effects of letrozole

Posts.Content: It might help you yo talk to the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Periods on fec-t

Posts.Title: Second time around? Results tomorrow

Posts.Title: diet

Posts.Title: Well didn't expect those results

Posts.Content: I know you are bound to worry but even if the diagnosis is cancer the care and the treatment you will have is first class. Treatments have improved so much in recent years and survival rates are improving all the time. I hope you have your mind put to rest. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: hi

Posts.Content: I know where you're coming from because I had ALL my nodes removed and they were ALL clear. Yes, there is an increased risk of lymphedema, but if you take sensible precautions you can lower the risk. Initially I was completely paranoid but you get used to taking precautions and it becomes second nature. I think if you work by the rule LET NOTHING PUNCTURE THE SKIN ON THE AFFECTED ARM, you'll be fine. By nothing this means: injections, blood-pressure cuffs, insect bites, sunburn and scratches received whilst gardening. If you do accidently scratch yourself, wash it immediately and apply antiseptics. Some doctors will allow you to have an open-ended prescription for antibiotics. I'm six years post surgery and have escaped the dreaded lymphedema. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Don't know whether to laugh or cry

Posts.Content: The problem is caused by the surgeons cutting through nerves and when the nerves start to knit back the 'rewiring' goes bonkers! People who have had limbs removed have similar problems.  I know this is little consolation but if you accept this as 'normal but annoying' you may find it helps. Best wishes KateG

Posts.Title: Soya or not? HER2+ Report after meeting dietician

Posts.Content: Your poor mum seems to have been going through the mill - twelve years, wow, it must have been quite a trial. You don't say how old is your mother? As a rule they use Letrozole (Femara) on post-menopausal women and Tamoxifen on pre-menopausal women. Both drugs supress oestrogen in different ways - please go to the 'Cancer Information' tab at the top of the page and then navigate to   'Breast Cancer' 'Hormone Treatments' where they explain the difference way these drugs are targeted. As far as I know there are no other comparable drugs on the market but both Tamoxifen and Letrozole (Femara) are well tested and respected drugs. My surgery was initialy delayed (for other medical reasons) and I was put on Femara as a 'holding measure'. It did me a BIG  favour because the Femara shrank the tumour so much that the surgery originally planned was changed so that I needed less radical surgery. It might help you to talk to one of the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Is there a new drug better than Tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: I had a second operation to ensure clear margins and it was a doddle. Okay I had drains and was a bit sore but nothing like the original surgery. Something to look out for is a seroma - a collection of fluid near the scar tissue which builds into a swelling. It doesn't always happen but if it does then insist it is drained. My breast care nurses didn't want to know (I was a private patient) and refered me to the Consultant. The seroma was drained three times before it settled down but it didn't cause any long=term problems. Physiotherapy - horrible but worthwhile. It really does help if you do all the exercises. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: what to expect after surgery

Posts.Content: Welcome Jane - you have certainly come to the right place. I understand that your emotions are all over the place - you wouldn't be human if you just shrugged it off. I remember the complete shock, the uncertainty, the terror so I really do understand. What I found helped me was once my treatment was underway I felt I was doing something. Having a treatment plan in place focuses your thoughts and you can look at it as a series of hurdles to jump and when you get to the end of treatment you feel more positive. Best wishes, KateG

As to Letrozole - okay there may be some side-effects such as hot flushes but these soon settle down but what a small price to pay to kick cancer's butt? Also remember you may be able to change to another form of hormone treatment. I was on Letrozole but changed to Tamoxifen because I could use locally applied oestogen on Tamoxifen. Best wishes KateG

Posts.Title: op

Posts.Content: They should tell you (but just in case they don't lol) not to use any perfumed products on your skin because it can interfere with the radiotherapy. This means no; body lotion, shower gel, deoderant, talc - you can only use Simple unperfumed soap. To help to keep the skin supple you can use a specific cream which they normally have on sale in the hospital shop. It is cheap and you get large tubs of the stuff. Radiotherapy has a cumulative effect and whilst I sailed through the first couple of weeks, the tiredness crept up on me and lasted for several weeks after my treatment had ended. Be kind to yourself and take it easy - have a lie down when you get home. Another tip which, strangely helps with the tiredness is to up your fluid intake - this means water not beer lol! Good luck with the rest of your treatment. KateG
Posts.Title: starting radiotherapy

Posts.Content: It is very rare for such a young woman to be diagnosed with breast cancer. Is it a definate diagnosis? Or is she just being investigated? There are a number of stages to diagnosis - ordinary mammogram, a more specialised mammogram, a fine-needle aspiration, then a core biopsy, possibly other diagnostic tests will also be done. I do hope it isn't cancer but if it is then I'm sure you will be a great support and comfort to your daughter. Please post again when you know more. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: 25 year old and breast cancer

Posts.Content: Oh Sharon, I'm so sorry. As I said before, it is so rare for such a young women to be diagnosed with BC. I have no medical knowledge but I imagine the medics will do everything to kick cancer's butt. This will probably involve a series of treatment; surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, followed by five years of a hormone therapy (if appropriate). There are practical things you may do; all depending on her circumstances. Does she have a husband? Does she have children? Does she have siblings? You may be able to support her by looking after children, cooking her meals, taking her to hospital appointments. I know I was grateful for any help offered. Best wishes KateG

Posts.Title: 120mm tumour

Posts.Content: I can understand your concern but a correct diagnosis is not something that can be a "One Stop Shop". The routine diagnosis pattern is, mammogram, another more specific mammogram (using a more sophisticated machine), a fine needle aspiration, then a core biopsy, followed by other ultra-sound scans. These aspirations and biopsies need to be given to medical technicians for them to analyse. The medics (surgeons, technicians, radiotherapists, oncologists ) meet and discuss the findings and decide, as a team, the best course of treatment for the individual patient. They will all be cooperating to decide how best to help YOU! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Do docs play down cancer until they get biopsy results or can they...

Posts.Content: Oh Sweetheart... your poor body has been (and still is) going through the mill and it is understandable you are exhausted. Radiotherapy, whilst not painful in itself, does leave the patient feeling whacked out. It seems radiotherapy accumulates in the body and whilst the first week or so you feel okay it gradually builds up and the effects last for a few weeks AFTER treatment ends. One tip which got me through it was to 'drink lots of water' - I don't know how it works but IT WORKS. You must also 'listen' to your body - if you feel tired then have a rest. Don't try and be 'Super-Patient' - lay back and get someone to peel you a grape. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy.

Posts.Content: Radiotherapy does not hurt but you do need to take good care of your skin with lots of perfume-free moisturising cream. Use 'Simple' fragrance-fee soap, pat the skin dry. Do not use any perfumed products on the breast area; this means; no perfume, talc, soap,  or deodorant because some of these products contain trace elements of metal which react with the radiotherapy rays. Radiotherapy can  also cause fatigue which has a cumalative effect so towards the end of treatment you can feel really washed out. It really helps if you keep well hydrated so drink LOTS of water (not gin lol!) . It will be over before you know it! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy - after Nipple Excision surgery [DCIS]!

Posts.Content: Often friends and family would like to help but don't know how - so tell them. You don't have to be as blunt as me but when they visit, and they say, "If there is anything I can do to help?"  Smile sweetly and reply "Funny you should ask, but I really could do with some help keeping the garden tidy." Then keep the tea and cakes coming. Best wishes KateG

Posts.Content: I had 25 sessions of radiotherapy but did not experience any pain like those you describe. Under my breast became sore and the skin split but that was AFTER radiotherapy. I think (I'm not medically qualified) that the pain you are experiencing is more likely to be as a result of your surgery. As the tissues heal the nerve-endings sometimes go a bit hay-wire and send shooting pains through the breast and underarm (from lymph node removal). Don't be fobbed off my medics - they are not gods! If you're in pain then let them know and demand answers.! (Feminist rant over lol!) Best wishes KateG

Posts.Content: Please don't be too concerned about delays - my sugery was delayed because I had other health problems so from diagnosis to surgery was three months. As a holding measure I was put on hormone treatment and it actually did me a favour because thedrugs shrank the tumour so much that the surgery I had  was not as radical as originally planned. I had private treatment but the only difference was that I had my own room in hospital - all the rest of my treatment was the same as NHS. I would certainly recomend having radiotherapy as close to home as possible as it can be very tiring. Treatment for BC has come on by leaps and bounds in recent years and survival rates are excellent. Best wishes KateG

Posts.Content: I take Tamoxifen too and, whilst I'm not medically qualified, I believe it may affect mood. Initially there is so much going on; examinations, tests, surgery, chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy, then when active treatment ends we are 'cast adrift'  to ponder on our own mortality. I suggest if you still feel low that you persist in telling your GP about how you feel until they take you seriously. Best wishes, KateG

Bear in mind that they have removed the cancer and rads are used to mop up any stray cells - it is belt and braces! Best wishes KateG

Posts.Title: lumpectomy

Posts.Content: I am NOT medically qualified in any way but from my scant experience I would be more inclined to think that it is your thyroid which is responsible for your lethargy. Arimidex does have acknowledged side-effects like hot flushes but these do settle down within a few months. Do ask your GP for a blood test to check your thyroid function. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Arimidex? Help!

Posts.Content: I had the same dilemma although I'm 65 and my child-bearing years are way behind me. The oncologist at my five year check brought up the subject of continuing taking Tamoxifen for another five years and I groaned. He said it had been successful in trials but it was up to me whether to take it or not. From what I understand the effects of Tamoxifen continue for ten years anyway and, given my age and that I had a grade 1 tumour, I decided against continuing. I'm far more likely to fall off my perch from something other than BC. I stopped taking it in April and am still waiting for the side-effects to subside. Obviously for you it is different but do discuss it with your oncologist and ask for their honest opinion. Perhaps you can have another child and THEN go back on Tamoxifen? Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: 5th year Oncology check - more tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: My dear fellow BC 'beauties' - I am so much further on in my treatment and I really want to reassure you all that there is light at the end of the tunnel. I was diagnosed five years ago next month but because of complications I couldn't have surgery until the following January. I am currently ploughing my way through the last six months of Tamoxifen until my final oncologist appointment in March 2013. It has been (especially at the beginning) a really sh*ty journey, but you can get there too! BC survival rates are REALLY GOOD! Best wishes KateG

Posts.Title: Mouth problems

Posts.Content: I am not medically qualified and only speak from experience. Anything I say should be  confirmed by a proffessional. My guess would be that you have a seroma - this is a gathering of fluid near to the site of the wound. If you can imagine the yellow fluid generated when you have a graze on your knee... then that is the fluid that builds up in a seroma. It can be drained by a medical proffessional and it will relieve the pressure and therefore any pain. Best wishes, KateG

Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and Citaloprin

Posts.Content: So sorry to hear your daughter is having a problem taking this drug. All the hormone drugs have side-effects but they generally settle down after a few months. I took Letrozole before changing to take Tamoxifen and have done so for the prescribed five years. Okay, initially there are things like the odd hot flush, but within a few months the body settles down and it becomes like taking a vitamin pill. What is most important is that Tamoxifen PROTECTS  us from BC reoccuring. If your daughter is concerned then show her this post and if you want me to message her then request my friendship so I can send you/her a private message. Best wishes KateG

Posts.Content: One of the problems caused by surgery is that they cut through lots of nerves and during the process of healing when they knit back together it can cause pain. No-one can be expected to just 'put up' with pain so please go to your GP and ask for a prescription for pain-killing tablets.  I suffer chronic back pain and I wore a path to the G.P's surgery until they prescribed the drugs I needed. Best wishes KateG
