The thing that suprised me most was how numb and heavy my upper arm felt. The feeling gradually wore off but there are still areas of my arm into which I could stick pins and not feel anything - not an action to be reccommended lol! I agree you should really take care of your skin on the affected arm; don't allow the medics take blood pressure or blood or inject that arm. Wear gloves when you're gardening and use insect repellent and avoid sunburn too because that can compromise the skin. I'm nearly five years post-surgery and my scar is hardly noticeable. Good luck with your surgery and let us know how you get along. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Lymph node removal

Posts.Content: A cold is the last thing you need on top of everything else! I'm not medically qualified but I understand that the medics will give you a blood-test before chemo and if they detect any problems (like a virus) then they might delay chemo. Drugs to RELEAVE infections will only do just that - they won't CURE they will only relieve a headache, unblock a sniffle, or soothe a sore throat. I do hope  some of the other wonderful women on this site will also be able to offer advice. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Cold medication

Posts.Content: Sorry Betty, I can't answer your question but suggest you 'phone the lovely nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone number 0808 808 0000. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy after implant reconstruction

Posts.Content: I don't have any medical qualifications but I think you need to discuss this with someone who does so please call one of the nurses here on this site on freephone 0808 808 0000. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Breast lump hardened and sore during fec chemo - is this normal?

Posts.Content: OMG! You poor thing! This procedure is completely new to me so I don't think you are alone in being confused. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Embarrassing Nipple Moment

Posts.Content: I think we all yearn for life to 'get back to normal' but we have to accept a 'new normal'. Having a diagnosis of cancer pulls the rug right out from under us and it takes a while to adjust. Relationships change (my husband is now SOOOOO protective toward me), our body shape changes - I've been battling with weight issues all my life but Tamoxifen certainly does not help! I'm now four years post-surgery and it DOES get easier - promise! Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: low confidence issues :0(

Posts.Content: My sister died of BC and I am four-and-a-half years post surgery so, naturally, my daughter is VERY breast aware. She has had numerous examinations, fine-needle aspirations, mammograms etc. which, thankfully, have all proved negative. However, at least she has peace of mind - and so you deserve the same. DO NOT BE FOBBED OFF! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Second opinion - lump?

Posts.Content: It is perfectly normal and will  wear off in time. I had all my lymph nodes removed five years ago and at first the whole upper arm was numb and heavy but it has gradually regained most of the feeling although there are still some places into which I could stick pins without feeling a thing! Not something that should be done of course because of danger of lymphodema. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: numb feeling under arm after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Wow! You're brave! I thought I was going to lose my nipple but fate decided otherwise. I would suggest you call one of the lovely nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Nipple Reconstruction

Posts.Content: I understand from the Breast Cancer Care site that many BC patients opt for an (excuse the spelling!) oopherectomy - removal of the overies rather than take hormone treatments. Hope it works for you! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Removal of ovaries

Posts.Content: Hi, At the top right of your page you will see a block which includes the words 'Ask a nurse'. Simply click on the words written in blue and then write your question. Hope you find some answers. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: oestrogen receptive cancer???

Posts.Content: When my darling sister died of BC, her 'born again' husband decreed that at the end of her funeral the church bells should be rung....as "The Heavens Greet Our Sister". Inwardly I was screaming - "NO! Not YOUR sister...MINE!" I will NEVER deny anyone their beliefs but I expect they also respect MY non-belief. KateG
Posts.Title: How to stop / deal with religious comments

Posts.Content: Once you have been touched by BC you become 'paranoid' about every little twinge, ache, niggle... whatever. I've had investigations for: spinal secondaries and bowel seondaries... both, thankfully, clear,(Both symptoms put down to 'old age' - thanks a bunch!)  but you become SO vigilant. Whilst it might be right to be cautious we can't let this rule our lives. KateG
Posts.Title: emotional after effects

Posts.Content: A difficult question.... I had an early menopause but was prescribed with HTR which took me through the 'worst' years. I came off HRT about 8 years before I was diagnosed with BC at the age of 59. Taking Letrozole and then Tamoxifen brought on hot flushes for a short period but then settled down. It may be that your hormones are doing double summersaults, but only your medical team will have definite answers. Do tell your medical team about this and ask their advice. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Hot flushers

Posts.Content: Oh course it bothers you and of course you need a resolution but I don't know enough medical knowledge to be able to offer advice. I can only say that any surgery is a pain and no result can be a guaranted 'back to normal result'. Okay, I still have my left breast but there is NO WAY I would want to show it to anyone. My left breast is damaged by surgery and radiotherapy whilst the right breast is heading south at an alarming rate. It is a small price to pay for our healh. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Does it stay llike this?

Posts.Content: It seems you are not alone as it is an experience many of us have gone through. One friend ( fit and healthy and with her own car) who lived five minutes away did not visit or call once wheras another friend (aged 78 and frail)  walked a mile, then caught a bus and then walked another mile to visit me. Yes, it is a nasty shock to discover that people you thought of as friends abandon you in your time of need but it is a sure way to find out who are your real friends. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: How to deal with how people react

Posts.Content: Oh Sweetheart.... please don't put up with pain! It seems sometimes that unless you make a BIG fuss you are deemed to be 'coping' and are then ignored. I have severe spinal pain and I had to wear a path - backwards and forwards to my GP until they recognised my needs and helped. So - rattle cages and DEMAND help. Sending big cyber hugs! KateG
Posts.Title: unbearable pain

Posts.Content: I hate to see an unanswered post so that is why I refer people to the nurses. They really are helpful and can help when perhaps we can't. They have so much more knowledge than me and perhaps they are better qualified than me to answer anyone's questions. Best wishes to you all, KateG
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy after implant reconstruction

Posts.Content: I think we can all say we were terrified when we got or diagnosis and everything is so overwhelming however, nothing in my treatment was   anywhere as bad as my imagination. Once you start treatment you get some of your power back and feel you are doing something positive to kick cancer's butt. As to the question of tablets, not everyone takes hormone tablets - they are only prescribed to those women whose cancer is oestrogen-positive. Best wishes KateG (A nearly six-year survivor)
Posts.Title: Just been diagnosed BC

Posts.Content: Oh Sweetheart.... we all have meltdown days and you are entitled to have a wobble. I will back the others and say "STOP GOOGLING"! If you have any questions please talk to the nurses here on this site - they operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Feel like I am back at square one

Posts.Content: Hi to everyone - reply to Amanda It is still early days Amanda, your scar will settle down - honest! Radiotherapy will alter the breast making it firmer... and yes the other one still continues its journey south due to age. The best things you can do  whilst undergoing radiotherapy are: avoid putting anything perfumed on to your skin because it can react with radiotherapy, so no deodorant, no perfumed soap (use Simple soap) no bubble bath or shower cream, keep skin moist with Aqueous Cream (often sold in hospital shops), pat skin dry after washing and keep out of sun or tanning salons. I would also avoid wearing a tight bra - anything that rubs against the skin is to be avoided.  Some people sail through radiotherapy without any problems, others do have skin problems. I wish you luck with your treatment. KateG
Posts.Title: Body Image - Lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Why not ask the nurses here on the site? They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone number 0808 808 0000. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Contact Lenses

Posts.Content: I think its normal to have a wobble. Everything is normal, everything  is going along swimmingly and then BANG we get all emotional. So don't beat yourself up about it - it happens to us all! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: emotions arghhhh

Posts.Content: Oh Sweetheart... read my Profile Page if you want to know how many SCARY scenarios I have been through. It is all very well to say, "Don't worry, it will be all right" but once touched by cancer we become 'paranoid'.... every lump, bump, pain, twitch becomes the big 'CANCER NIGHTMARE' and whilst it may be good to be cautious, we can not let it rule our lives. Give the 'elephant' a big kick lol! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: new pain and worried!

Posts.Content: Oh you poor thing, I have veins which go, 'dive, dive, dive' every time someone with a needle approaches me.  You could ask if you could have a port put in to avoid  further torture. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: mid line put in and 1st chemo done : )

Posts.Content: I had a scan just before surgery. It was an ultra-sound - like the one they give to pregnant women. I think it is more to establish exactly where it is situated. Good luck with your op, and remember nothing is as bad as you imagine it will be! Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Sorry, I can't help you but suggest you call one of the nurses here on this site tomorrow. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Asthma drug Prednisolone (Asthma) before my op in 10 days

Posts.Content: Yes, treatment can hit you for six and it takes a while to recover but it sounds to me as if you are feeling depressed. Why not have a chat with one of the lovely nurses here on this site? They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. If that doesn't help then make yourself an appointment to see your GP and lay it on the line - tell them exactly how you feel. If it helps, write it down and hand it to your GP to read. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: staying positive

Posts.Content: I had an axillary clearance four and a half years ago and at first my upper arm was heavy and numb. Feeling has gradually returned but there are still areas into which I could stick pins without feeling pain (something that is not reccommended lol!). They cut through nerves during surgery and it takes a while for the nerves to 're-wire' themselves in order to send the right signals. As to hot flushes - are you taking any hormone drugs like Tamoxifen or Letrozole? These drugs will cause hot flushes. I've not heard that radiotherapy causes hot flushes. It is important you keep your skin moisturised during radiotherapy - okay you say you are wet wiith sweat, but as long as you are dry and moisturised immediately before a radiotherapy session you will be okay. What is important is to keep your skin clear of any perfumed products because they can react with the radiotherapy. If your skin breaks down during radiotherapy there are treatments - clear salves and dressings which can speed the healing process. I found the nurses were much better at dressing and helping than the doctors. Don't 'put up with things' - you are entitled to care! Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Hot Sweats and radiotherapy !

Posts.Content: I'm sorry I don't know the answer but I'm sure the wonderful nurses here on this site will be able to offer advice. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Taking a tonic

Posts.Content: My sister died of BC so when I developed BC I asked for genetic testing. I had to fill in a really long form listing all my relatives ages and cause of death. Some of these questions are difficult because some relatives died young or of causes other than cancer. I think to get a definitive diagnosis of familial cancer you need a detailed family history. As to the treatment you received, each case is taken on the detail of the diagnosis. They will have had a group meeting of all those involved in your treatment and decided on the best possible programme of treatment for YOU. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Help! New family info has me scared

Posts.Content: The very word 'cancer' freaks us all out - I remember hearing that word and then every subsequent word turned into "zzzzzzzzzzzzzz" I was going to die.... I was going to suffer.... I do not say this flippantly because my much-loved sister died of BC in 1993.  However, what I have learned since my diagnosis five years ago, is that  a diagnosis of BC is NO LONGER A DEATH SENTENCE. Treatments have taken leaps and bounds forward and the recurrance rate is now only 5%. Yes, it is scary, Yes, it can be a hard journey through treatment, but we are HERE and we have kicked cancer's butt! Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: friends and family freaking me out :(

Posts.Content: Oh Sweetheart, it sounds as if you are suffering from more than the cancer. The problem is that relatives feel SO helpless - men especially feel they ought to be able to FIX everything and illness is beyond their control and they feel emasculated. I'm fortunate to have been in a long relationship and my husband was with me all the way but he only showed the 'cracks' to our two daughters. They witnessed him tense, angry, and unable to FIX me. I found I had to reassure HIM... so good luck with that! Don't stop talking... keep reassuring him. Yes, I know that is the wrong way round, but that is the way forward. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Relationships and cancer

Posts.Content: It is a scary scary time! When we are first diagnosed it seems as if it is the 'End of the World' but there is hope... and there is life.... after BC. Treatments for BC are well-targeted as each case is different, each patient is an individual. Some patients have a 'bucket-load' of treatment whilst others have fewer hoops through which they need to jump! I have lots of other health problems but the doctors do take these things into consideration when designing your individual  treatment plan. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Help needed - B C treatments Rad and Tamoxifen side effects with Fibromyalgia...

Posts.Content: If only the medical profession had an inkling of the stress they cause with the delays. I often felt like I was on a very slow-moving conveyor belt and I expect you both do too. It may be that you need to rattle a few cages and demand some answers - don't be a 'patient' patient lol! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Waiting....and waiting.... doesn't it cause more stress?

Posts.Content: Do you have any swelling under your arm? If so it may be you are developing a seroma - a collection of fluid caused by the surgery. A seroma is a clear fluid rather like the fluid that oozes from a graze in the skin, which causes a painful swelling. This can be drained by medics if needed. However, whatever the cause, please do NOT put up with pain but go to either your BC nurse or your GP. PLEASE do continue with the exercises to improve movement because they are SO worthwhile! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: pain after surgery

Posts.Content: It is difficult to answer the question when I don't know what stage of treatment or diagnosis you are going through. It really does help us to help YOU if you fill in your Profile Page. If you are downhearted because you've only just been diagnosed and then 2014 will bring only treatment I can understand you might find it a bit daunting, I was diagnosed in the October but couldn't have treatment until the following January so I was tied up in knots all over that Christmas and New Year. However, the following year was much better because it was all over, but I did have a wobble when I heard the song "I will survive" by Gloria Gaynor. Breast Cancer is so treatable and has 85% survival so the odds are very much in your favour. As for therapy - I found going to the bottle bank and dropping bottles in from a great height so I heard the 'smash' - very satisfying! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Bah humbug

Posts.Content: It might help you to talk to one of the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: nervous about starting chemo

Posts.Content: It helps the others at the start of their treatment to hear success stories such as yours. They will feel better knowing that all the treatment is worthwhile. Congratulations! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: More Good News

Posts.Content: I had rad burns under my breast which appeared about ten days AFTER the end of radiotherapy. I saw my Radiotherapy Consultant who prescribed xy and Z but it was the NURSE who knew what she was doing and applied a clear gel and dressings which were 'plastic-like' on the side applied to the wound which did not stick. I'm sorry I can't remember the names of these dressings and drugs but can say - there is treatment out there and it does work and, YES, sometimes you need to rattle a few cages in order to get treatment. Yes, 'thump tables' and 'rattle cages' - don't suffer in silence! KateG
Posts.Title: dressings for rad burns

Posts.Content: Sorry you have not had a reply yet but you may have better luck if you join the Breast Cancer Care site on www.bcc.org . This site will have more members and the likelihood of members near to your address. Hope you find others nearby because local support is so helpful. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: High Wycombe hospital

Posts.Content: Creative writing as therapy.... you are spot on! For anyone in turmoil to put thoughts into the written word is the best! Well done. KateG
Posts.Title: Creative writing therap! Poem came to me some time after the events...

Posts.Content: I can't answer your question but suggest you join another online community named Breast Cancer Care. I'm sure the members there will help you. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Onkatype Dx

Posts.Content: Sounds a bit like the left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing? If you are taking one of the drugs (Femara and other Letrozole drugs) they should offer annual bone scans because there may be a problem caused by these drugs.  Do not simply accept answers - demand answers - it is YOUR body! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: so confused

Posts.Content: Aw! The waiting is the pits and your imagination is often worse than the reality. I didn't have a mastectomy but a lumpectomy and an axillary clearance (all of my lymph nodes removed) but I can remember the horrible feeling of my stomach turning over. What did surprise me that after the surgery I felt very little pain, I was just a bit sore. Sending you a big cyber hug KateG
Posts.Title: Upcoming mastectomy op on 18th

Posts.Content: So sorry you haven't had a reply but suggest you may find help and advice from the wonderful nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Hair loss... Again?? - Advice please

Posts.Content: My skin broke down during and after rads so you have my sympathy. My radiotherappy team prescribed a cream and dressings. I don't know  about aloe vera but suggest you either ask the radiotherapy team or speak to one of the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: blisters

Posts.Content: It might be a good idea to see a chiropodist as they have all the tools to sort out your nails. Unfortunately you need to pay and treatment starts at around £22. The only time you can get treatment on the NHS is if the nail problem is caused by another medical condition like diabetes but I'm not sure if you would be eligible or not. You could ask your GP and see if you are. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Brittle nails

Posts.Content: Hic Debs How wonderful of you to want to extend support to other 'newbies' to this crap disease. It might be an idea to talk to one of the wonderful nurses/advisors here on this site and I'm sure they will be able to point you in the right direction. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. I try to help by becoming a Community Champion here on this site and it may be something n which you may be interested? Perhaps talk about this scheme when you contact the nurses/advisors? Best wishes KateG I
Posts.Title: 2 Years down the line

Posts.Content: I would always check out suspect aches and pains if only for your peace of mind. I would suggest you contact your oncology team rather than your GP. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Lower Back Ache

Posts.Content: Oh yes - we all feel that way because it brings the whole BC treatment experience back and we're all scared sh*tless. I'm five years post-treatment and am now having two-year gaps between mammograms and I still get the old 'butterflies-in-the-stomach' feeling. I know it is scary but, hey, isn't it better to catch the little blighter sooner rather than later? Sending lots of courage.... KateG
Posts.Title: check ups and mammograms

Posts.Content: I belong to an informal group of BC patients and we meet up around every month to six weeks. The main subject of conversation is often around weight gain and diets. I have been on a permanent diet since my diagnosis and have lost three stone, whilst I have watched the others pile on the pounds. One theory is that the hormone tablets increases appetite. I have had doctors remarking to me about hormone tablets causing weight gain too but whether there is any scientific basis to this theory I do not know. All I know is it is jolly unfair - BC the gift that keeps on giving... argh! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Arimadex

Posts.Content: Thank you! We are all "Sisters doing it for themselves". Hope you have a happy and HEALTHY New Year too. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Happy New Year to everyone

Posts.Content: People tend to leave the site after their treatment has finished so your request may fall on deaf ears. What I can tell you is each patient may have a completely different treatment regime depending on their particular cancer. I know of patients who have had a mastectomy and no other treatment (apart from daily hormone pills for five years) who are still alive and kicking over five years after diagnosis. I know of others who have had lumpectomy, axillary clearance and radiotherapy - and yet others who have had everything thrown at them. It is horses for courses.I belong to a local support group and we meet every month for a pub lunch. We compare treatment plans and each one is different - some who have had chemo have also NOT had their lymph nodes removed and vicsa-versa (sic). I suppose we would need to be qualified oncologists to begin to understand. Trust your doctors - they should know what they are doing. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Anyone still here who was Stage 3 and no chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Susan, On the top right of your page you will find a box which contains, amongst other things, the words Ask a nurse written in blue. Click on this and it gives you a 'phone number to call and an email link. Hope this helps. Best wishes, KateG

Posts.Content: I know how scary it is to have your treatment delayed. My surgery was delayed by months because I had shingles over the affected breast and I was sooooo worried. Michelle is right - best to get yourself fit before you start chemo so your body has the best opportunity to deal with chemo. Best wishes, KateG

Posts.Title: Follow up scans/mammograms post treatment!

Posts.Content: Congratulations on all your good news. They doctors don't really say - "You are completely cured", the hedge their bets and say "No evidence of disease" or NED for short. I've been NED for four years, and fingers crossed, you'll be a NED too. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: end of treatment

Posts.Content: I have been taking a hormone drug for five years and the side-effects do settle down after a few weeks. It is a good idea to take the tablet last thing at night. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Side effects with Anastrozole (Armidex)

Posts.Content: Please don't think 'It has come back' - think the b*gger wasn't properly kicked out the first time! Cyber hugs KateG
Posts.Title: don't know what the hell to think anymore : (

Posts.Content: Oh Sweetheart, no wonder you need to talk! Please do take the opportunity to speak to the wonderful caring nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone number 0808 808 0000. I needed to have a second surgery to make sure they got the little b*gger and the docs will do everything they can to get your 'little b*gger'! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: don't know what the hell to think anymore : (

Posts.Content: I am concerned  about your question because your friend's story does sound incredible. I wonder if your friend has been told the truth? With breast cancer which is hormone sensitive having HRT is NOT THE CORRECT TREATMENT however it may have been confused with the drug Tamoxifen which has the opposite effect. I think you need to gather a few more facts and figures. KateG
Posts.Title: HRT

Posts.Content: I only had a lumpectomy but they didn't find clear margins. They did  further surgery to take more tissue and then I had clear margins. I imagine they will  do the same to you. It's a nuisance but my recovery time from the second op was no problem at all. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: No clear margins!

Posts.Content: I am not medically qualified so I don't know if radiotherapy to the axillar is, or is not necessary, so I suggest you talk to one of the lovely nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. Sadly, you will have to wait now until Monday to 'phone but, in the meantime please don't worry; you can be sure your doctors will be doing their best to treat you correctly. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Not having radio on node area.

Posts.Content: Me again - do 'phone the Mac Help-Line on TUESDAY - roughly office hours - 0808 808 0000. The nurses are soooo helpful. KateG
Posts.Title: problems with funding

Posts.Content: My husband (big strong he-man type) showed little emotion at my diagnosis. I only realised his concern when my second surgery (to remove margins of cancerous tissue) was delayed and he 'LOST THE PLOT.  I was patiently waiting on the ward - a bit pissed off because I hadn't had anything to eat or drink for HOURS, athough I had found solace in cleaning my teeth repeatedly. Men are not GOOD at expressing emotions. I have been married for 42 years and I'm still trying to figure him out... BLESS! Please don't think the worst... they are frightened rabbits caught in the headlights. KateG (A member of the stronger sex!)
Posts.Title: Husband response - not that interested?!

Posts.Content: Oh, Sweetheart... it does sometimes feel like everything piles in on us and we are entitled to have a wobble. There is a group on this site named 'The Room' which is a special place where you can rant, scream... or whatever you want to do... and then slam the door on 'The Room'. It is a great place in which to vent your feelings. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: not really to do with my bc but so upset

Posts.Content: Sorry, I can't answer your question but suggest you ask one of the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Hair advice pls

Posts.Content: So sorry to hear you're worried - I think we would all feel the same. I can't help you but suggest you 'phone the nurses helpline on the site: 0808 808 0000 Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm. They are really kind and helpful and perhaps they can put your mind at rest. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Wheezing - advice?

Posts.Content: This is awful! Give me time and I WILL FIND SOME 'PHONE NUMBERS! KateG
Posts.Title: problems with funding

Posts.Content: Difficult question! I have some personal examples - one - my sister; two years after mastectomy and radiotherapy she developed spinal mets which were treated with radiotherapy. She continued living in good health for another nine years before devoloping mets in her womb.She had a hysterectomy and chemo but died a year later - tem years after her diagnosis and aged 54. A friend, now aged seventy, was initially diagnosed aged 55 - had lumpectomy and radiotherapy had cancer develop in her other breast some 11 years later. She had mastectomy and a recon. I was diagnosed five years ago and treated months later. In March 2013 I go for (hopefully) my final appointment with my oncologist. I will then go back on the three-yearly mammogram programmme.. THEN I might become a survivor. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: When do you graduate to being a BC SURVIVOR and stop being a patient...

Posts.Content: BRILLIANT!!! KateG
Posts.Title: Saw this and it made me smile

Posts.Content: Good for you! I'm just content to take my dog for a walk (using walking poles to keep me stable!). Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: things to do when this is all over

Posts.Content: So sorry you're feeling so yuk! Do have a word with the wonderful nurses here on this site. The freephone number is 0808 808 0000. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm. You may also find it helps if you increase your fluid intake - water not vodka lol! Also bear in mind pain-killers can cause constipation, which is another reason for increasing fluid intake. It might also be a good idea to ask your doctor to prescribe a stool-softening drug. Wow - this cancer treatment is SO much fun lol! Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Headaches after Tax

Posts.Content: Sorry you're feeling low. You don't say your age which may be relevant. I'm sixty-three and have a lot of joint pain  but I have made a groove in the road to see my GP and complained... and complained until they took me seriously and prescribed anti-inflammatories and painkilling drugs. Don't be fobbed off - keep complaining until they sort out suitable medication. With the fatigue - again this may be age-related. I'm on Tamoxifen too and I think this may be a contributory factor in fatigue. However, when I was having radiotherapy and was on my knees with fatigue, the radiotherapist told me to drink more water and it definitely helps. (Don't ask me why!)  Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Fatigue

Posts.Content: Annie - don't be in too much of a hurry to see the top banana - they generally only see the very difficult cases or 'interesting cases' lol. Yes, continuity would be much better but Registrars are equally well-qualified - there are so many consultant posts to go around. Sascha - it seems you have had some real stinkers of medical staff so you carry on throwing darts. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: DARTBOARD !!!! Dedicated to thoughtless Oncologists............

Posts.Content: Hi, and welcome to the group. I know it is scary when results and treatments are delayed and it has happened to so many of us and we can sympathise. My treatment was delayed for months - I know it freaks us all out because we want to kick cancer out of our bodies ASAP. However sometimes it pays to take things slowly; the delay in my surgery meant I kept more of my breast than was originally planned by my surgeon. Feel free to rant... freak out... moan.... whatever... we are here for you! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: delay to pathology reports

Posts.Content: Sorry, I can't answer your question but suggest it might help you to talk  this over with one of the wonderful nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9AM TO 8PM ON FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Docetaxel / Abraxane

Posts.Content: Hi Tracy, The nurses are correct - you have been through an awful regime of treatment and it is not at all surprising you feel you have been run over by a bus. It will take time but slowly you will regain your strength. However, if you are really concerned then go to your GP. It might help if you write down exactly how you're are feeling in case they misunderstand you or you forget something. Lots of people feel frustrated that they don't get back to 'normal' after treatment but you will recover to perhaps a new but different 'normal'. Don't despair - you will get stronger. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: life after cancer

Posts.Content: Oh crumbs - it is a bit of a technical question? All I can say is that a friend of mine had a mastectomy, no chemotherapy, no radiotherapy but letrozole for five years. (That was eight years ago.) I had a lumpectomy, radiotherapy, and Tamoxifen for five + years. Everyone's treatment varies according to the their diagnosis. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: DCIS, IDC, Mastectomy, No Rads, No Chemo, Tamoxifen.

Posts.Content: I imagine your mum is of the 'old school' never wanting to complain? I think she might need you to ask questions on her behalf because there are drugs to counteract the side effects of chemo and they should have been prescribed. Of course it is a really good idea to keep up her fluids - lots of water helps to flush out the chemo. I really think it would help you to discuss this with one of the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Advice Needed

Posts.Content: You may have more luck making this appeal on the Breast Cancer Care site . Hope you find someone with whom to share - I met some other BC patients through the BCC and we meet up around every six weeks and have lunch... and you wouldn't believe the laughter we generate. Other customers in the pub would not begin to imagine what we have in common ! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: any on near nuneaton

Posts.Content: One centre of excellence is The Royal Marsden Hospital, Fulham, London. You can pay for a private appointment where they don't examine you but read your medical notes, scans, etc.  and advise on treatment. I don't know whether they could do it for you as you live in Spain but it is worth a try. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Chemo for invasive lobular cancer

Posts.Content: The number is (the code for the UK) followed by 0207 091 2230. It is not a freephone number but after your initial contact I believe you can organise calls using skype. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: New to the group

Posts.Content: Welcome to the group and do keep posting if you have any worries. You might benefit from talking to one of the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. It will certainly be good to take someone else with you to your appointmment but you might also want to take a list of prepared questions. You could also ask if you may record the consultation - some doctors allow it whilst others don't but it is worth asking. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: New to the group

Posts.Content: The Mac Support line has all sorts of experts and if, when you initially call, you mention that it is financial advice you require they will put you through the right expert. Call FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000 - Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: borrowing money

Posts.Content: I didn't have chemo but fervently believe that you DO NOT HAVE TO PUT UP WITH PAIN. Please don't think you 'have to put up' with anything; you are not to be a martyr - you are a person in pain and entitled to demand help from the medical profession. Kick butts! KateG
Posts.Title: Arm pain ?

Posts.Content: This is my pet subject! I have a list of does and don'ts: Do NOT let any medic touch the affected arm - this means no blood-pressure test, no injection, no blood tests. Do NOT allow anything to puncture the skin on your affected arm - this means wearing gardening gloves and wearing insect repellant. Do NOT get sunburned. Do NOT carry heavy loads on the affected arm. DO your excercises to promote mobility. Do ask for a refferal to a Lymphodeoma nurse. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Arm swelling - what can I do to prevent lymphodema?

Posts.Content: The thing is with any of these alternative drugs is that they take time to settle down. I found Letrozole a pain but once I changed to Tamoxifen (and given it a few weeks) I continued to take it for five years. Once I stopped taking it (with the doctors permission) I felt exactly the same.  So why not give it a go? Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Alternative to Tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Oh, Sweetheart.... what you are feeling is natural. I was scared witless too but I had a similar diagnosis -I had slightly more tissue invovled, but I'm here five years on and I can tell you it is NOT all bad news - you can get through this too. The survival rate for BC patients is in the 80% - 95% range. DCIS is a 'good' cancer diagnosis. We all go through this horrible roller-coaster of emotions; one year after treatment I was getting out the Christmas decorations and remembering that when I was diagnosed I thought it might be my LAST Christmas - then Gloria Gaynor was on the radio singing, 'I will survive'... and I was a gibbering wreck. Yes, the paranoid feeling goes... 'You will survive'! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Feeling paranoid, dare I think of a future

Posts.Content: I have been taking it for around four years. I had been taking Letrozole (Femara) but it had caused gynealogical problems so changed to Tamoxifen. All these hormone drugs have side-effects - hot flushes, joint pains, night-sweats but they do settle down with time.... and what price a prolonged life whilst it kicks the BC in the butt! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: has anyone had any possive experiences with Tamoxifen????? Am due...

Posts.Content: Because my sister died  of BC I went for genetic councelling at The Royal Marsden. Before I visited the hospital they sent me loads of forms asking for health of not only siblings and parents but grandparents, aunts and cousins. Because it was only my sister who had had cancer they decided not to pursue it any further. They did, however, give their backing to both my daughters and my niece having mammograms before the age of fifty. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Genetic testing

Posts.Content: Yes, the end of active treatment does feel like you are being 'cast adrift' but they do keep an eye on you with regular check-ups. As to getting back to normal - you find you can not turn the clock back but you gradually find a 'new normal' . What is really important is not to run before you can walk. I know I tried to do too much too soon and my body let me know and protested! Remember, you've all been through some harrowing treatmment so please be kind to yourselves. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: What now ?

Posts.Content: Oh Sweetheart... I would be just as confused! It sounds to me as if there is no need for immediate action and that the medics are just checking it out to be on the 'safe side'. If they were really concerned they would not "leave it until June". I think it would be a good idea for you to talk this over with one of the lovely nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. The medical profession do not 'muck about' with possible cancers.... they act quickly if it needs action. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Confused!

Posts.Content: You may find it useful to discuss this with one of the wonderful nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone number 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Nipple reconstruction

Posts.Content: If you want us to help you then you need to give more information. I clicked on your name to find your account details and there was no personal information. Your mum could be 40 or 100 and so it makes it very difficult to offer appropriate advice. We don't need your 'inside-leg style' information but some background would enable us to offer appropriate help. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: mum to make decide on reconstruction, can anyone help?

Posts.Content: Oh Sweetheart, as if BC isn't enough you really have had a double-whammy and it is so unfair! The only advice I can offer is suggest you talk to one of the wonderful nurse/advisors here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: permanent hair loss

Posts.Content: I'm sorry gerty but I don't know the answer but do 'phone the nurses here on this site for advice. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: nail has fallen off

Posts.Content: Of course you are worried but it  is far more likely to be an infection than a reoccurance. Red and swollen screams 'INFECTION'. Also remember that the reocurrance rate of BC is 5%. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer reocurrence

Posts.Content: My surgeon decribed the build-up of fluid which causes a seroma as the same sort of fluid which escapes after a scrape of the skin - a thin yellow fluid. I had a whopping seroma which was drained many times and, once, when witnessed by husband, a pint of fluid was drained.... and his face drained of blood too...lol! Hope you're feeling reassured, KateG
Posts.Title: Wound leaking

Posts.Content: I belong to another on-line community 'Breast Cancer Care' and people often advertise meet-ups on their forums. Someone might write 'Anyone from the North Surrey area - fancy a meet-up?'  A group of us met up in this way and we are now 'Ladies who Lunch' on a Saturday around once a month. Being able to talk to other patients who have been or are going through the same thing is wonderfully supportive. If you live in a big place like Edinburgh you are bound to get some response. Do join 'Breast Cancer Care' and give it a try. As to radiotherapy and tiredness - been there! It does drag you down for a while but it WILL wear off. One tip given to me was to drink lots of water and it helps. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Feeling Guilty

Posts.Content: I hope your BCN could help but it does sound as if you need medical attention. It seems odd it should happen three weeks after surgery. I know some BCN's are notoriously difficult to contact so if that is the case either get onto your GP or go to A & E. Let us know how you get along. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Wound leaking

Posts.Content: I asked this question of my oncologist and was told: 1) Once the little b*gger has been surgically removed and then 2) after chemo and radio then 3) after two years have passed without secondaries developing  4) after five years of hormone tablets. I have done 'my time' - five years last September/October since diagnosis, now five years since surgery, final mamogram in March.... hopefully final chat with Consultant... then "bog off.... you are discharged!"  Flags OUT. Not boasting ladies... proving it can be done. It is a long road but you WILL reach your destination. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: When does survival start officially?

Posts.Content: Sorry, I can't answer your question but suggest you join another on-line community 'Breast Cancer Care'. It is only for those with BC and I'm sure someone there will be able to help. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: New breast cancer treatment

Posts.Content: Sorry, but as far as I know the rule with radiotherapy is no perfumed products whatsoever It seems there are minute traces of metals present which react with the radiotherapy rays. You might ask if you can use something like vaseline. Best wishes, KateG (Love your new 'signature'- very positive!)
Posts.Title: Rose hip oil and radiotherapy

Posts.Content: I'm sorry no-one has been able to advise you but I suggest you join another on-line community named Breast Cancer Care where you might find patients with similar experiences.  Personally, I do everything the medics tell me on the grounds they've spent years training! (lol) Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: breast cancer after heart surgery

Posts.Content: It would seem that statistically more men abandon women when their wife/partner has cancer than visa/versa. What does this say about men? Well, there are GOOD men out there and those   of us who have loyal partners must count our blessings. However there are a lot of shallow sh*t bags out there and, by showing themselves in their true colours, we can be relieved they have gone! I am so sorry you man has proved to be unworthy but look to the future when a genuinely nice man will come your way. Meanwhile... you have this great circle of SISTERS here on this site! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: I can't cope anymore

Posts.Content: Oh you poor thing - you're going through a horrible time but it WILL pass. You feel as if you're in a dark tunnel but there is light at the end of this particular tunnel. Try to find something to plan as a treat at the end of your treatment. You could plan a party or a short holiday - just create something to which you can look forward to doing. Sending cyber hugs KateG
Posts.Title: TIRED AND SICK WTH FEC

Posts.Content: Sorry, I can't help you but it may help you to talk to one of the advisors here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: raigmore hospital

Posts.Content: Oh Sweetheart... you are in a horrible place - no woman wants to lose something - a breast - which is SO important to our identity as a woman. I so much feel for you and I wonder if you have been offered alternative treatment? Okay, you can have reconrsuctive surgery, but it is still an awful trauma and you have my every smpathy. Cancer is such a curse but prompt treatment does help to guarantee  a more succesful outcome. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: rambling thoughts

Posts.Content: The nurses here are wonderful and I'm sure they will be able to advise and support you at this frightening time. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on 0808 808 0000. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: out of hospital today and really feeling low

Posts.Content: Please don't worry about the bone density scan - it is very quick and straightforward and is done to monitor your bone density which can possibly be reduced when on some hormone treatments. What you are feeling is SO NORMAL! After all the flurry of activity during diagnosis and treatment is over we all feel like we've been abandoned on a life-raft in the middle of the sea. It has been a traumatic experience and you are bound to doubt your health because it has just let you down big-time. It does get better with time as you gradually recover your strength. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: anxiety

Posts.Content: I've had several checks for mets which turned out to be other things but once you've had cancer once you do get jumpy! I've also had appointments brought forward which does send your imagination into overdrive. Waiting for results is  definately a form of torture but remember that if (a VERY BIG 'if') they do find something then the quicker it can be treated. Let us know how you get on and meantime I'll keep everything crossed for you! Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: RE: Should I fear the worst

Posts.Content: Welcome from me too. It is a very scary time but treatments are improving every day. If you need answers, either medical or social, then the nurses here on this site are very helpful. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: hello

Posts.Content: .So glad to hear you've got good results; I know how worrying it can be to have these doubts hanging over you. I found the best form of therapy from a mutual support group. I belong to another on-line community 'Breast Cancer Care' and someone posted a notice saying something like 'anyone in the North Surrey area'. Because the Surrey branch of The Royal Marsden Hospital is in Sutton, Surrey, a number of us responded to the posting and now meet informally about once every six weeks. We have a pub lunch on a Saturday and just TALK. It was a bit awkward at first but we gradually started comparing symptoms, treatment, doctors etc. What surprised me most was the laughter... we laugh about such silly things... certain doctors and their funny ways, the humiliation of hanging around radiotherapy in skimpy gowns, and the feeling of being a 'beached whale' trying to get off the radiotherapy table. We also talk about things like the side-effects of the hormone drugs and swap tips. It really helps to be with others who have been through the same or similar experiences. If you can start the ball rolling in your area then I'm sure it will help. I did a small film for Macmillan talking about this and you can find it on YouTube; "Macmillan Kathleen's Story". Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: RE: Should I fear the worst

Posts.Content: They kept moving the bl**dy goal-posts! First it was five years from diagnosis - I was diagnosed in September 2007. They then told me it was five years from surgery - that was January and February 2008. Then.... surprise... it was five years after the end of 'active treatment'. So my final five-year mammogram and 'chat' with oncologist will be five and a half years from diagnosis. (I started taking hormone tablets in September 2007 and and will continue to take them until I am (hopefully) discharged after my final annual mammogram in March. From then on, if I am discharged I will go back into the 'system' and have a mammogram every three years. I really hope I will 'pass' my final test and graduate with 'Honours' lol! It can be done! KateG
Posts.Title: When does survival start officially?

Posts.Content: If you have large breast or slightly drooping breasts you can have soreness and itchy in the fold under the breast. This nothing to do with cancer and is more likely to be a mild fungal infection caused by perspiration not being able to evaporate. Try to keep the area dry and even stick a dressing or hanky in the crease. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Sore itchiness

Posts.Content: Diagnosis isn't always simple and often involes a number of tests to define exactly what is what. The normal regime of tests involve: simple mammogram, specialist mammogram, biopsy, core-biopsy, and various scans. B.C. has a number of forms and it takes time to define so please don't be concerned that you haven't had an 'instant answer' diagnosis. Each patient is different and each diagnosis is different. There is normally a meeting of all the specialist teams: surgical, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy where they discuss and plan an individual treatment regime tailored to YOU! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Delay with Diagnoses

Posts.Content: Dealing with a diagnosis is such a challenge and so it is small wonder you had a few 'dodgy' moments, but you have proved  strong enough to come back and kick cancer's butt! Well done and big cyber hugs! KateG
Posts.Title: Back from negative to positive thoughts

Posts.Content: It might help you if you speak to one of the nurses here on the site. The freephone number is 0808 808 0000 - they operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm. I have read posts about this in the past and it is suggested that you wear a very dark nail polish to help prevent damage. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Very sore fingernails.

Posts.Content: Oh dear... how difficult? I really can not advise but I know one of the wonderful nurses here on this site will be able to help. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Acceptable time to wait for a mastectomy and reconstruction?

Posts.Content: I am four years post-surgery and can not WAIT until I am free of Tamoxifen! I have a mammogram tomorrrow, then a chat with the oncologist in the middle of April. I then start the last year of my 'cancer sentence'. I know I will never be free - none of us is immortal. KateG
Posts.Title: 5 years clear

Posts.Content: Hi, I had shingles which prevented surgery for several months which, fortunately, was a blessing because the drug, Femara, managed to shrink my tumour sufficiently enough to reduce the extent of the surgery required.. I had two lots of anti-viral meds before they did surgery but my radiotherapy was only delayed because I had a problem with moving my arm far enough above my head  to make radiotherapy possible., Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: SHINGLES

Posts.Content: My daughter has been plagued by 'lumpy' breasts and every time it has turned out to be cysts. The medical proffession take all lumps seriously and if (AND IT IS A BIG 'IF') they will act swiftly. Even if it is BC the survival rate for BC is excellent. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Painful Lump

Posts.Content: Oh Sweetheart, that is rough! I am amazed they treated you as a day surgery patient. I had a lumpectomy and an axillary clearance and I was in for three days. I hope you are being well looked after and that someone is mopping your brow and peeling you a grape. Cyber hugs KateG
Posts.Title: Had MX, wish I had stayed in over night

Posts.Content: Once we have been diagnosed with cancer any lump or bump seems horribly threatening and scary but it is far better to have it checked out than let your imagination work overtime. My daughter (aged 47) is always discovering lumps and bumps, and, given my history and that her aunt (my sister) died of BC, she regularly beats a path to her GP. However, praise be, not one of the many lumps has ever been found to be cancerous... but better to be safe than sorry, eh? Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: A new lump

Posts.Content: I have heard the phrase 'Peri-Menopausal' mentioned by daughter (aged 47) who asked me if I thought it was a good idea to ask for Hormone Replacement Therapy. Of course I gave birth to my daughter aged 17 (really!) but even though I have had BC I still encouraged her to go for  HRT. A bit more of a problem for you, as you already have been diagnosed with BC - I honestly don't know if there is a connection between HRT and BC. I also took the 'Pill' in the 60's and 70's so I again, don't know of any cause or effect for that drug either. Talk to the experts? Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Chemo induced Menopause after BC/ Triple Neg

Posts.Content: So sorry you haven't had a reply. I imagine it is a bit too technical for the patients here. Perhaps it might help you to talk to one of the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Strattice

Posts.Content: I had armpit pain and numbness at the same time which sounds ridiculous but true. I had all my lymph nodes taken out and it does take a while for the nerve-endings to knit back together. I'm now over five years post surgery and my arm is still numb in places and I have occasional pain but as I take some pretty strong painkillers for my back pain I can manage arm pain at the same time. Do not suffer in silence and ask for painkillers. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: arm and armpit pain

Posts.Content: The nurses here on the site are very kind and helpful Do call them - Monday to Friday - 9am to 8pm on 0808 808 0000. I'm sure they will be able to expalin everything. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: What does it mean when it has progressed in to blood vessels?

Posts.Content: I took Femara for three months before surgery and it shrank the tumour so much that I didn't have to have the surgery originally planned - it saved my nipple and aerola. So, thanks Femara! Saying this, you may still want to discuss this with a medic so I suggest you 'phone the wonderful nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000 . Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: query

Posts.Content: Oh it is great to hear of positive news. I'm sure you can face the remaining chemos knowing it is working to kick the b*ggers out. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Chemo is working - yippee

Posts.Content: Great news! You give hope to those just starting. Thank you. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: There is light at the end of the tunnel

Posts.Content: You seem very young to be peri-menopausal but I suppose there is possibility. I don't have an medical knowledge but it might help you to have a chat with one of the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Chemo induced Menopause after BC/ Triple Neg

Posts.Content: Three cheers for the Royal Marsden - Sutton Branch! The team there is the BEST!  Okay, treatment for BC is NOT a walk in the park but they know what they are doing! TRUST THEM. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Mars den hospital Sutton

Posts.Content: So sorry I can't answer your question but suggest you talk to one of the wonderful nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: How do you feel physically after FEC

Posts.Content: I'm sure as long as you take the recommended dose you should not become addicted but do have a word with your chemo team if you need reassurance. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: The dreaded seroma

Posts.Content: Happy New Year to you too and I hope the rest of your treatment goes smoothly. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Hickman Line

Posts.Content: You have my every sympathy because I too had one and thought it would NEVER go away. The good news is it WILL go away eventually but it is such a pain whilst it remains. I had mine drained again and again, it started out as pint, but then the amount of fluid drained lessened each time until it was down to a quarter of a pint. Some medics don't like doing repeated drains because they say there is an increased risk of infection. You can use ice-packs (wrapped in a towel) to ease the pain and of course take painkillers (they're not just for headaches lol!) Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: The dreaded seroma

Posts.Content: Yes, diagnosis and treatment feel like a hurdle race! Before I had one people were telling me that they would give me earphones with which I could listen to music - huh! I just had thirty or so minutes of listening to banging clunky and clicking. Hope you were more fortunate. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: MRI Scan - that's another test ticked off. It's all a learning process

Posts.Content: We are all here to help one another and if you need answers someone will try and answer your questions. I notice you have not filled in your Profile Page but please may I encourage you to give some details because it helps others to help you if we know something about your diagnosis and treatment. You don't have to give your life history and we don't want to know your inside leg measurement lol! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Thanks so much for your support

Posts.Content: Your poor body has taken an enormous battering and it will take time to get back to strength. I won't say 'back to normal' because you have to accept a 'new normal' which, by the way, is not too far away from the 'old normal'. I had my treatment four and a half years ago and will be signed off (hopefully) next March. It took me a year to get back to some normaility but I still get the odd twinge from my axillary clearance scar. A little dig to remind me lol! I found I needed to set myself little goals and take things easy. I had been the 'bull in the china shop' type of person rushing from one task to the next but found I could no longer behave that way. You'll get there... but remember to be kind to yourself. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: When do i get "Me" back

Posts.Content: Oh, I'm so sorry you're feeling this way but let me reassure you that we all feel panic stricken once we've been touched by cancer. Every little twinge and pain is magnified and our imagination goes into overdrive. You need reassurance and you need to either contact your Breast Care Nurse or your GP as soon as possible and explain exactly how you feel. If you feel lost for words WRITE IT DOWN. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Scared and Worried

Posts.Content: You are not alone - I was never given written results either. I trusted my oncology team to give me whatever information I needed. Unless we have medical training ourselves, I can't see that having details of our diagnosis would serve any purpose. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: i never saw results

Posts.Content: Oh sweetheart... don't put up with this! Rattle medical cages... demand answers! You should not be left in this situation. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Any suggestions Please!

Posts.Content: Laying face down!!!!! I was on my back and that was bad enough! My every sympathy! KateG
Posts.Title: MRI Scan - that's another test ticked off. It's all a learning process

Posts.Content: I changed to Tamoxifen and my symptoms were kept under control - especially the vaginal dryness. With Tamoxifen you can be prescribed a locally applied hormone cream. As to whether it will help with the depression - I don't really know but I felt a whole load better. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Anastrozole & Depression.

Posts.Content: I agree - don't be embarrassed about mentioning your symptoms - better to be safe than sorry. It may turn out to be trivial but at least you will know what's going on and be able to do something about it. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: first 6mth check up

Posts.Content: I do hope you have an answer from a fellow patient soon but in the meantime it might help you to talk to one of the wonderful nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: 1st saline expansion

Posts.Content: 'Skin so Soft' dry oil body spray by Avon works well as an insect repellent. Someone told me about this and at first I was sceptical but I used it all last summer and wasn't bitten once. I have a garden pond which acts like a magnet for midges but, for some reason they don't like the spray, and the bonus is it smells nice. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Lymphodema risk and insect repellent

Posts.Content: Well done! It is one hell of a journey and it is great to cross the finishing line. I don't want to put a downer on you but you might find yourself a little 'lost'. After all the activity of constant treatment and hospital appointments you are discharged and it may feel (I did!) that you have been cast adrift. It takes a while to readjust to so-called normal life. If you still need us... we are here for support. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Finished treatment today

Posts.Content: Just a few more positive promotions for conventional treatments; there are 48,400 new cases a year but 95% will survive for longer than ten years. In 1970 only 80% survived (still really good odds!). There was a documentary recently which suggested that within the next few years BC would become a 'chronic' disease - ie one that could be kept at bay for many years allowing women to live a natural life-span. Another person who went down the alternative therapy treatment was Caron Keating. She espoused healthy diets and sunshine and sea in Australia but eventually succumbed to the disease. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: If they have done a sentinel node biopsy and not found anything and they are not considering a clearance, then be advised by them because you don't want to risk lymphodema for no gain. Okay lymphoedema isn't life-threatening but can be very debilitating. Do everything to protect your affected arm: no blood-pressure cuffs, no needles, no insect bites, and no cuts. Best wishes, KateG

Posts.Title: "On A Light-Hearted Note ........"

Posts.Content: I am surprised your sister's doctors have laid out these options and asked her to make the decisions. It seems that every case of Breast Cancer is treated individually - some have chemo first whilst others have it after surgery. Then there are patients who have a lumpectomy with only radiotherapy and no chemo. I think your sister should ask her doctors what treatment they would recommend and follow their suggestions. Obviously the more treatment you chuck at this disease the better but it is sooooo treatable and survival rates are brilliant. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Any advice Welcome

Posts.Content: PLEASE may I encourage you to go down the convential route because it WORKS. Doctors and scientists have studied for years and years to come up with this treatment. I know its not pleasant but it is doable and it saves lives. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: The cost of treatment does not make any difference. I was treated privately and had EXACTLY the same treatment as those on the NHS. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: I take Tamoxifen and yes, it does have side-effects. Everyone reacts differently; some notice no difference whilst others have varying degrees of side-effects. It, as Paddyman says, effective in stopping a recurrance of breast cancer so it is worth taking. If you should have severe side-effects then your oncologist can switch you to another brand. I started off taking letrozole (Femara) which shrunk my tumour so much it resulted in less radical surgery, for which I was truly grateful.  However as time went on I switched to Tamoxifen as it suited me better. Best wishes. KateG
Posts.Title: Any advice?

Posts.Content: Okay, I didn't want to 'scare' you with anecdotal stories but if you want to know the POSSIBLE (AND I MEAN POSSIBLE) side-effects then, you MAY experience: Mild 'hot-flushes' experienced by women going through the menopause Occasional 'night-sweats' again, experienced by women going through the menopause Vaginal dryness. When taking Tamoxifen you can be prescribed locally applied oestrogen cream which helps this problem You can also request a vaginal lubricant called 'Sylk' from your doctor on prescription. One advantage of taking Tamoxifen over other hormone drugs is that you can use the oestrogen cream - with drugs such as Femara - you can't! One tip - most GPs don't have any idea about hormone drugs and don't realise that some of these drugs (such as Sylk and Gynest) are availble on prescription.  Best wishes, KateG

Posts.Title: Chemo,trials, lumps and coil pin thingy's

Posts.Content: I didn't have a mastectomey but a WLE and axillary clearance. I have weird sensations particularly in my upper arm and arm-pit. Whilst those areas are numb to the touch I still have shooting pains. I discussed this with my oncologist who told me that because they cut and damage nerve-endings during surgery the nerves can sort of cross wire and send out incorrect signals. Hope this helps. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: phantom feelings

Posts.Content: I had an axillary clearance a few years ago. The numbness in the upper arm was severe at first but now it is less troublesome. There are still areas which are numb and into which I could stick pins  without feeling anything. Because many nerves are cut during axillary clearance this can cause both numbness and pain which seems contradictory but is a fact. The pain does calm down with time and, like the previous contributor, I would reccomend persevering with the excercises. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Pain after axillary clearance

Posts.Content: Same here - left-handed and left axillary clearance. For the first few weeks my arm felt very heavy and numb but I did my excercises (as per orders from the physio!) and recovered good movement. Four and a half years on and areas of my arm are still numb - could stick pins in it and not feel a thing... something NOT to be tried because of the danger of developing lymphoedema. Guard your arm against any puncture wounds: no injections, no blood-pressure checks, no blood tests, and beware of any breaks in the skin. If you do gardening make sure you wear thick gloves, avoid sun-burn, and avoid any biting insects. Like I said - don't break the skin! I may be sounding paranoid but it is better to PREVENT lymphoedema because you can't CURE it, and whilst the condition in itself is not life-threatening it is painful and best avoided. Tips for rads: slap on the cream, avoid ANY perfumed products, and VERY IMPORTANT drink lots of water. You need to keep up the fluids because it really helps with the tiredness. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Chemo finished, lymph removal,then radiation

Posts.Content: Waiting for results is very scary and your imagination is probably doing overtime. I can't tell you everything will be okay but what I can say is - it is MUCH better to catch something early.  The sooner any treatment is begun the better. I wish you the best of luck. KateG
Posts.Title: Scared of whats to come... if anything

Posts.Content: It took me around six weeks before I could drive. I was very nervous at first  and had to do a couple of trips around the block to get used to driving again. It took me longer to get my arm above my head in order for radiotherapy to start. Again, excercise helps (sorry to nag!) Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Pain after axillary clearance

Posts.Content: Yes, it is a bit of a poser! It seems a lot depends on the grade of the cancer, and the preference of the surgeon. When I discussed this with my surgeon he explained the difference between a sentinel node biopsy an axcillary clearance and I asked which he recommended. He said the clearance was the safer option. I belong to an informal group of BC patients and what I have noticed is that all of the women who are on the heavy side have had a clearance (including me). Of course this may be a coincidence but I do wonder if there is a connection. I suggest you try and pin the surgeon down and ask exactly why they want to do a clearance. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Lymph node clearance

Posts.Content: Yes, it is true that it can cause problems like lymphodema but as long as you are take care of your arm you should avoid problems. This means not breaking the skin on that arm  if at all possible - no injections, no blood-pressure cuff, no blood tests , avoiding sun-burn, avoiding insect bites, and always wear gloves when washing up or gardening. If you do break the skin then wash it asap, put on anti-septic cream and cover. I know it always sound as if you need to be paranoid but it becomes second nature. Secondly, although they use the phrase axcillary clearance, it is rare that they take every single one, besides which the lymph nodes under the other arm compensate to some degree. Hope this helps. Best wishes KateG

Posts.Title: waiting time for adjuvant treatment

Posts.Content: Oh Emma! I would like to join you in a kicking competition to kick cancer's butt! Words of comfort can sound trite and 'fluffy' but I do know,from the progress of my sister's breast cancer journey, how things can progress. She was diagnosed in the 1980's with an aggressive cancer and had mastectomy followed by radiotherapy. She had two years clear before bone mets which were treated with radiotherapy. She then had around seven years of normal life before other mets  occurred. Bear in mind how much the treatment of cancer has progressed since the 1990's and hopefully you can see the trees for the woods. Big Cyber Hugs KateG

Posts.Content: Everyone deals with radiotherapy in their own way; so much depends on how young and how fit you are at the start. Posts.Title: DIEP Flap after implants

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear you're having a problem sleeping but it is hardly surprising when you have such a lot to cope with. I'm sure we can all understand and have experienced the same. You can try things like lavender oil on a hanky on your pillow and a hot milky drink when you go to bed. When you wake in the middle of the night you can also try mumbling some sort of rubbish like "fluffy bunnies" over and over again to crowd out the negative thoughts. (It works for me!) If you are not having radiotherapy then you need not worry about smelly stuff. Radiotherapy patients need to avoid anything perfumed on their skin because chemicals and traces of imetals in things like soap, talc and deodarants react with the radiotherapy rays. Keep skin moisturised as normal and have a word with your GP about your sleep problems. Best wishes, KateG

Posts.Content: I agree with everything Saxxy has written. Posts.Title: Acceptance

Posts.Content: I used to blame EVERYTHING on Tamoxifen (including Global Warming...lol!) however - ALL the hormone-suppressing drugs: Tamoxifen, Letrozole... et al have the universal side-effects, all of which mimic those when hormones are removed from the body during the menopause. This means premenopausal women will suddenly be acclerated through the menopause, whilst post-meopausal women will have similar symptoms. Initially, they will go through hot flushes etc. but these will settle down with time. What you say you are experiencing I am inclined to believe are a coincidence. Okay - this whole treatment regime is a pain in the bum but I don't think your swollen glands are anything about which you need to worry. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: 2 weeks on tamoxifen swollen throat glands is it a side affect ?

Posts.Content: I had lymphoedema and can attest to how uncomfortable it can become. My doctor withdrew the fluid from it - first 1pint, 2nd time 3/4 of a pint and so on down to 1/8th. It was not in my breast but a swelling to the top of my breast. I think the nurse will show you manual drainage (a sort of massage). I don't think you can do anything before you see the nurse... except swear a lot LOL!  Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Breast Lymphoedema.

Posts.Content: Sorry you're feeling so rough. Please ask for more help with the constipation - there are remedies. It will also help if you increase your fluid intake because the constipation medication needs extra fluid to enable it to work. Chemo is bound to knock you down but listen to your body and take it easy and remember it WILL pass. Best wishes, KateG

Posts.Title: My Good News

Posts.Content: I had a node clearance and it left me with a four inch semi-circular scar. As Wendy says, they do cut through nerves and so you are left with a strange mix of sensations. At first I had no feeling in my upper arm - it was completely numb. This gradually faded, although there are still areas of my arm into which I could stick pins without feeling aything! I occasionally have sharp stabbing pain in the same area but nothing to 'write home about'. My drains were removed after three days which, on refelction, was far too soon because I was left with a seroma (a swelling caused by fluid) which caused problems. Although it may seem hard at first it is worth persevering with the arm excercises because it does help improve your range of movement. I was very scared before the start of my treatment but NOTHING was as bad as my imagination told me it would be! Best wishes, KateG

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed in the October but didn't have surgery until the following January because I had shingles over the affected breast. They did however put me on the drug Femara as a 'holding' measure. It helped because it shrank the tumour so the surgery was subsequently less drastic than planned. I`do feel for you because I was like you - I just wanted the bl**dy thing gone!  I think you are entitled to be cross given the ineffecient was in which your case has been handled. You could contact the PALS (Patient Liasion) office of your hospital and ask their advice. They are generally very helpful. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: 51 day wait from cancer diagnosis to first treatment! Anyone else...

Posts.Content: I was initially prescribed Femara (Letrozole) but, because of vaginal dryness leading to infections, I was prescribed 'Gynest' - a locally applied  oestrogen cream. This was only allowed if I  was prescribed with TAMOXIFEN. For some reason I could only use Gynest with Tamoxifen. Also the use of Gynest should be limited because 'feeding the cancer tumour which is hormone receptive' with a hormone cream could cause problems. I now use Gynest twice a week with the 'blessing' of my Oncologist.  The Oncologist who prescribed the use of the locally applied oestrogen cream is a 'A BIG Cheese' at The Royal Marsden hospital . Best wishes KateG
