Posts.Title: Hospital Stay

Posts.Content: Hi Maureen Jean, Further to your comments on worries about use of your arms post-surgery, yes, it will be difficult and uncomfortable at first but it is worth persevering with the stretching exercises. I had my post-op radiotherapy delayed because I couldn't raise my arm up sufficiently but I kept on (and on, and on!) doing the exercises and now I can stretch my arm in in straight line up above my head. The physios at my hospital held a class for post-op patients and emphasized the need to do these exercises daily FOREVER because of the risk of lymphoedema developing (even 10 years on from surgery) if you don't keep the arms moving. As to post operative pain - I was worried and expecting to wake up in agony - I didn't. The surgeon explained that they inject a local anesthetic along the line of the incisions which dulls the pain until the healing process begins. And of course they also give you other pain-killing drugs. (Don't be shy to ask for something extra if you are suffering. It's all very well having a 'stiff-upper-lip' but come on - if it hurts ASK!) ALL THE VERY BEST KateG
Posts.Title: Post op problems

Posts.Content: Oh that is good news, Congratulations! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: lymph node biopsy clear

Posts.Content: I had an axillary clearance nearly six years ago. It left my upper-arm feeling very 'heavy' and numb and it took a while and some active physiotherapy to regain full movement. There is a very neat semi-circular scar which is barely noticeable. The surgery is worthwhile because, it is through the lymphatic system that cancer cells migrate to set up camp in other organs, so it is best to STOP the beggars in their tracks! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: axillery clearance

Posts.Content: Hi, I had my surgery (a lumpectomy and removal of 18 out of 20 lymph nodes from under my arm) in January and a follow up operation in February to take more breast tissue. I had severe swelling around the underarm scar which I was told was a seroma. It was drained by the doc three times - first time - half a pint, the second time - a third of a pint and the third time a - quarter of a pint! After about six weeks it settled down. I still have an area of numbness in my upper arm but it has improved dramatically. I think it is just of question of 'time will heal'. Boring but true! Good Luck. KateG
Posts.Title: Post op problems

Posts.Content: The anaesthetic takes a while to get out of your system so be kind to yourself and take it easy. Listen to your body - if you're tired then rest, if you feel thirsty make sure you keep hydrated because lack of fluid will make you feel tired . It took me ages before I could wear an underwired bra but there are some soft bras around - you could look on the website of Windsor Products.I wore their soft bras because I could not take the pressure wired bras put on my axillary clearance scar. You may be lucky and heal more rapidly. If you're worried about anything you can always talk to the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 9pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes. KateG

Posts.Title: Reconstraction.

Posts.Content: Of course you are bound to be very concerned about your mum but as the oncologists are involved it would seem, given clear scans, that her symptoms are not cancer-related.  I too have a crumbling spine which has caused extreme pain. This was investigated in case it was secondaries but after MRI etc. I was given the all clear and began a series of proceedures which now have it under control. Until she has all results she should be at least treated with painkillers, preferably morphine-based pills such as tramadol, zamadol and/or painkilling patches. You really need to be persistant with the doctors and keep on complaining about pain. As to the constipation it is a side-effect of painkilling drugs, so your doctor should be prescribing a stool-softening drug and your mum should also increase her intake of fluids . In my experience you have to rattle a few cages to get action. Best wishes, KateG

Posts.Title: Advice on reconstruction

Posts.Content: It is a common problem especially if you are taking hormonesupressing tablets. My consultant (a top guy at the Royal Marsden) told me that you can use locally applied hormone cream. Apparently you can only use it if you take Tamoxifen so if you are on any of the others like Femara ask your consultant to change the prescription. I use Gynest once or twice a week and it solved the problem. Don't suffer in silence. Best wishes, KateG

Posts.Title: Special Cushions

Posts.Content: I am an ancient with treated high blood-pressure (59 at diagnosis) with a left breast cancer and I had a lumpectomy and an aciillary clearance followed by four weeks of rads. When I was signing the consent form which stated that there was a 'possible problem of heart damage' the consultant radiographer (BIG CHEESE) said it was ridiculous that the warning was still on the consent forms because nowadays the radiotherapy can be aimed so accurately at the tumour. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy and radiation or mastectomy?

Posts.Content: I'm sorry I can't help you on this subject but it may help you to discuss this with one of the lovely nurses here on this site. Their number and operating times are on the right of this page. Sorry, just realised it only shows on the page when you click on 'reply'. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Paclitaxel - TAXOL

Posts.Content: It is the lymph nodes they removed from under the arm nearest the breast which put you in danger of lymphedema. So, yes - you must protect your arm from any puncture or pressure. However, you can also have lymphedema develop in the legs which are nothing to do with your cancer. If it is really nasty then first stop is your pharmacist then, if they recommend to do so  a visit to your GP . Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Mossi bite help needed

Posts.Content: Oh that sounds awful - you poor thing! You can take Tamoxifen post-menopause. I was taking Letrozole which is similar to Aromasin for a while but changed to Tamoxifen because I had minor gyne problems and could use a locally applied hormone cream with Tamoxifen but not on the Letrozole. Dear me, that is a badly constructed sentence but I hope you get my drift! Do ask your oncologist to change back but if he/she refuses then I'm sure the side-effects will settle down given time. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Aromasin side effects

Posts.Content: Yes... and scotch also hits the spot LOL! KateG
Posts.Title: Aromasin side effects

Posts.Content: You are still in shock but you will feel better once you have a treatment plan in place and you get back some control. Treatment for BC  has come on in leaps and bounds in recent years and survival rates are brilliant. Do stick to this site for information because there really is a lot of rubbish out there on the internet. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed.

Posts.Content: When you first hear the words, 'you have cancer'... you immediately feel scared. It takes a while to realise it is such a 'treatable' form of cancer and that the treatment is SO effective. Each patient has a unique diagnosis and therefore a unique treatment plan. It really helps when you have a 'treatment plan' in place - it acts as your 'road map' to recovery. You will get there! Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed!

Posts.Content: Big sigh of relief! I too had two lots of surgery because of unclear margins but the surgery originally planned was also less radical. Good luck for Friday. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Change of plan WLE not Mx - Hope!

Posts.Content: I do sympathise because I had a seroma for several months and know how painful it can be and the nuisance of having it drained. My seroma did eventually settle down and I hope your wife's will too. As for medical advice it might help you to talk to one of the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Seroma trouble

Posts.Content: I haven't used one but have read lots of posts in the past which praise them to the hills! Good luck! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Chillow - any good ?

Posts.Content: I had genetic counselling after my sister died of BC and I was diagnosed with BC The doctors agreed that my daughters and niece could have mammograms from age 40. The councellor wanted information dating back to mother, grandmother, aunts, great-aunts but they decided because no other family members had died of BC it was unllikely to be genetic. Obviously you need to be vigilant but please also put this into perspective; cancer is a ******** but it is also treatable. Best wishes KateG.
Posts.Title: breast & ovarian risk

Posts.Content: I have heard of similar diagnosis but can't offer any similar experience. I do strongly suggest you join another on-line community @Breast Cancer Care' where I'm sure you will find others who will advise and support you. KateG
Posts.Title: Breast cancer cells in lymph node but not in breast!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Ann, Well done, you seem much stronger. Yes, of course we want to know how you're getting on, please keep on posting. I'm sure you'll feel much more in control when you have the answers to all those questions. Post another blog to let us know of your progress. All the best, KateG
Posts.Title: Steamrollered - Whats the rush!

Posts.Content: As the patient - YOU have to lead... because friends and family are splashing around in the shallows. They don't know what to say or what to do and, whilst we may hope that people will rally round - they don't! I know it seems upside-down but YOU really have to (nicely) organise help. Lots of 'sweet smiles' and 'flattery' works wonders. "Oh, it would be so wonderful if you could: (Say) Collect the kids from school. Make a casserole so I can just heat it up for a meal. Take my  laundry to the launderette/dry cleaners. Help me with the ironing.... etc. etc. People genuinely WANT to help  but they often don't know HOW! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: your thoughts please-help should I have to ask or should it be offered...

Posts.Content: All the best to you too! Keep on kicking cancer's bum! KateG
Posts.Title: It is almost Christmas Day

Posts.Content: They cut through lots of nerves when they perform the surgery and the pain can be caused by the nerves knitting back together. I had pain and numbness at the same time which is weird. Both of these symptoms decreased with time but there are still areas of my arm into which I could stick pins without feeling a thing - something NOT to recommended! However if this pain is causing you so much distress do go to your GP and ask for some heavy-duty meds. Sometimes you have to be persistent  - I suffer from chronic back pain and I had to beat a path backwards and forwards to my GP until they got the message. Please don't put up with this pain - rattle cages! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Nerve pain or Letrozole pain ?

Posts.Content: This is a new one I've not heard of before. I suggest you ring the nurses here on this site on freephone 0808 808 0000. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm. It may be that you are allergic? Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Side effects of Letrozole

Posts.Content: Oh you poor thing - it does seem you've been dealt the s**t end of the stick! It is sometimes so hard to keep positive but treatment does help. Try and think of treats you can give yourself - simple things like a cream cake, a box of chocs or a long soak in a warm bath. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Not great scan results :(

Posts.Content: Hi Danger Mouse, Sorry you have had to join us but you've come to the right place. If you want to moan, groan, scream, rant or rave there will always be someone here to listen and understand. No need to put on a brave face here. It might be a good idea if you put a bit more information on your profile - the more we know, the better the quality of information and help we can offer. All best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Another new one

Posts.Content: Radiotherapy can wipe you out too! Your body has been through the 'mangle' and whilst we feel, 'okay, treatment done, now I can get back to how I was before'... sorry, it doesn't work like that. You have been through both a physical and mentally scarring illness and you will never be the same person you were before. You have to welcome the 'New Normal'. Accept it will take time to regain a degree of physical fitness, and don't 'beat yourself up' if you're not doing hand-stands or cart-wheels! Be kind to yourself. KateG
Posts.Title: Is this normal ?

Posts.Content: I think we have all scared ourselves by Googling illness - you focus or worst case senarios and your imagination goes into overdrive. If your oncologist says it is good news then that is what you should focus on and believe. If you want to talk it over with someone then why not 'phone the nurses here on this site. Unfortunately you will have to wait until Monday as they operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm. The freephone number is 0808 808 0000. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: newly diagnosed with adenoid cystic carcinoma in left breast

Posts.Content: I was treated at the Royal Marsden (Sutton branch) and I can not speak highly enough of the treatment I received. I assume you will be asking to be treated at the central London branch but all the Consultants work at both branches. It is a specialist hospital which only treats CANCER patients. All the surgeons are first class. The surgeon who treated me has sadly died (of cancer) but the oncologist to whom I am referred is Professor Stephen Johnson.  I would not want to be treated anywhere else. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Anyone been treated at The Royal Marsden?

Posts.Content: I belong to an informal group of BC patients and those of us  taking Tamoxifen have noticed a very fine growth of facial hair. I am very fair and the hair is only really noticeable to me but those with darker colouring feel it is more of a problem. I think some form of bleaching is the favoured option. It might help you if you discuss this question with one of the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on FREEPHONE 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen - hairy problem

Posts.Content: Hi Susan, People on this site often the call it the club no-one wants to join - black humour I'm afraid! Saying that, I'm sure you will find help and support from others here. It is obviously still early days for you and it is all very scary - we can all sympathise with that feeling. I had breast cancer but it was a known primary so I'm not exactly in the same boat, however I do know of other members who have the same/or similar diagnosis and I will contact them by PM and ask them to respond to you. Good luck with your treatment, KateG
Posts.Title: ? Breast cancer primary not found

Posts.Content: QUESTIONS: What surgery will I be having? Will it be a mastectomy or a lumpectomy (AKA a wide local excision)? Will I have a 'sentinal node' removed or have all nodes removed (AKA axcillary clearance)? Will I have chemotherapy? Will I have radiotherapy? What grade is my tumour (1, 2, 3, 4,)? Please take someone with you to the appointment because all you will hear is "cancer". Ask them to take notes and ask questions. Big  cyber-hugs... we are all here to support you! KateG Will I have hormone treatment?
Posts.Title: New to the Group

Posts.Content: I was post-menopausal but my treatment was delayed because I had shingles over the affected breast. I was diagnosed in the September but didn't have surgery until several months later. I was (at that time) on Letrozole which is another hormone drug and it shrank my tumour so that my surgery was less radical than originally planned. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: tamoxifen to shrink tumour pre surgery

Posts.Content: I am NOT medically qualified but I did read something about this suppliment recently suggesting it was helpful for those suffering from bone-thining. Patients using Letrozole are offered 'Bone Scans'. It may be a good idea to check this out with the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Calcium Suppliments ?

Posts.Content: Yes, don't worry, they will tag it on the end (they don't work Bank Holidays for example) but you could ask about hospital transport. It may mean hanging about for a while others are picked up or have their radiotherapy but it takes away the scary driving lol! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: What if I can't get to the hospital because of the snow for rads?

Posts.Content: I believe there are only around 300 cases of males being diagnosed with BC each year so finding others in his position will be difficult. You may find talking to the wonderful nurses here on this site who, among other things, wil be able to direct him to fellow patients. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes to you both KateG
Posts.Title: Men and Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: An elderly friend caught two buses and then walked half a mile to bring me a cuddly toy and a funny DVD. Love him to bits - a true friend! KateG
Posts.Title: Just for fun , the lovely things people have done for you ?

Posts.Content: I think you'd be better off 'phoning your oncologist's secretary first thing and asked her to check on these appointments. That should sort the matter out. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: CT Scan

Posts.Content: It might help you to discuss this with one of the lovely nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Pigs might fly......

Posts.Content: YOU are the VIP. You are the one going through treatment. B*gger everyone else. B*gger the world! It may seem this time lasts for ever... but it won't. There is light at the end of the tunnel. Cyber hugs KateG
Posts.Title: First FEC in the morning !!!

Posts.Content: I know how you feel about being abandoned! My husband's employer has BUPA cover too so I went private.The only difference I could see between private and nhs was that I saw a consultant instead of a registrar and I had a private room. The follow treatment was exactly the same as nhs, however when I asked the breast nurse to drain a seroma she said only the consultant could do it, which I thought was a load of toffee! The breast care nurses didn't seem to want anything to do with me. This site is a great support, do come on when you need help. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: NHS or private

Posts.Content: Each patient is treated differently - I had 25 sessions whilst a friend with the same (on the surface) diagnosis had 15. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Last hurdle!!!!!

Posts.Content: Yes, slap on the cream and avoid all scented products whilst you're having treatment. You may find as you get past the first half of your sessions that you will feel tired. I was told to increase my fluid intake and this means water - not gin and tonic lol! The treatment doesn't take long and is not painful - the most time is spent positioning you on the table to line up the tatoos. Good luck but I'm sure you won't need it. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Last hurdle!!!!!

Posts.Content: I have read this before and agree it really puts everything into perspective. I think that at the end of treatment one feels as if cast adrift on a life raft - for months the medical proffession has been 'all over us' doing tests, cutting, poisoning, and burning the cancer out of us and then... "Off you go now, it is all over. We will ask you back for check-ups.... bye! " Thank you for posting this link. KateG
Posts.Title: Getting to the end of treatment - then what?

Posts.Content: I was treated at The Royal Marsden Hospital (Sutton Branch). In certain radiotherapy suites (not all) photographs of lovely spring scenes - apple-blossom, bright blue skys, etc. were projected onto the ceiling so the patient on the radiotherapy table might view these scenes whilst undergoing radiotherapy. It did make an uncomfortable experience a tad more bearable. In another area of the hospital the scanning machinery was painted with zoo animal; presumably with children in mind. My dentist has images of Dublin Pubs on the ceiling... but none of these images cheer me; possibly pictures of blossom, blue sky, and fluffy clouds might cheer me for a while but when one is ill there is little that will penetrate that carapace. I think images which are bright and cheerful are the most appropriate. So: more 'blue sky, bright blossom, fluffy puppies, sea-scapes, ...anything which depicts escapism...please! KateG
Posts.Title: What can help in hospital?.... art?

Posts.Content: I am sorry you haven't had a reply to date so I am bumping this up to see if someone can answer this. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Kaitlin trial for HER2 positive breast cancer

Posts.Content: The waiting for results is HORRIBLE... and we have all been there and therefore sympathise. However, you have made the BEST choice and joined us here in Macland. What you should concentrate on is that the treatment for BC has come on  in leaps and bounds in recent years and we have an 85% chance of surviving for at least five years (and that's on five-year-old data). Keep posting here with any questions or comments and you will soon realise we are all here to hold one another's hands. Best wishes KateG (A six-year survivor... still kicking cancer's butt!)
Posts.Title: First post

Posts.Content: Very useful information. Thanks for passing it on. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: BOOKS

Posts.Content: Oh, wasn't that a lovely surprise! It is good to share such happy events here with your fellow Maclanders. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Count our blessings

Posts.Content: Oh Sweetheart, this is such a scary time but honestly... and I  mean honestly... BC is such a treatable condition. The treatments for BC have come on in leaps and bounds in recent years and has a BRILLIANT  survival rate. Okay, the treatment isn't a 'walk in the park' but it really is (as the saying goes) 'do-able'. I belong to an informal group of BC patients - all of whom have been through the cancer journey, and whilst they were (as I was) sh*t scared, we meet up every month and manage to not only understand one another but have a bloody good laugh. Lots of the women here on this site have been or are going through the same cancer journey so keep posting and keep asking questions - if we can, we'll try to help. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Diagnosed on Thursday

Posts.Content: You are bound to be stressed! Taking care of young children can be awesome - even though my 'bratlets' are now aged 46 ad 42... I remember the STRESS! Is there any family member around who can help? Is there a mum or a mother-in-law, a sister, an aunt... anybody around to help? Sometimes... and I know from personal experience.... we are TOO proud to ask for help. As for relaxation techniques....the best advice I ever had was concerned a saying; 'And this too will pass'. It covers all the bases... whatever is happening to us now... WILL PASS. But don't be too proud to ask for medical help... there is no stigma and drugs can help you deal with the stress. I have a spinal pain problem and one of the drugs I take is an anti-depperesent - it works! Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Complementary therapies/relaxtion

Posts.Content: Oh Sweetheart, what a pain! I honestly don't think the medics would lie to you - they're all about honesty these days. There was a documentary a few months ago where the doctors were saying that BC treatments are so advanced these days that very soon BC will become a chronic disease. This means the patient has ongoing treatment but will, as you say, die of old age. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Help Please

Posts.Content: Raloxifen - that's a new one to me! However it is working for you that is brilliant. Have you looked at the cancer information on this site, there may be something about it on there. You could type Raloxifen into the little search box at the top right of the page and see if it leads you anywhere. Failing that you could try Google. If it is so good I will be beating a path to my oncologists door because I'm no fan of Tamoxifen's side-effects. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Raloxifen

Posts.Content: NO  !!!!!! DOUBLE NO !!!!! Breast Cancer is Breast Cancer.... it is horrible.... treatment for BC is efficient and, more importantly, WORKS! Whilst we go through treatment it might seem we are going through our own 'Scary Movie' but we must also remember any woman who is diagnosed with BC has an 85% chance of still being around and kicking cancer's butt .... five years from now! YOU ARE NOT A FRAUD! Big hugs KateG
Posts.Title: Feel like a fraud on this site

Posts.Content: Oh... I know that feeling! Slightly different set of circumstances... my surgery was delayed and delayed for weeks because I had another health problem, then my radiotherapy was delayed for weeks and weeks because I had insufficient movement in my arm. Like you, I wanted it DONE and OVER but it would seem the mad urgency I felt was not what was needed. I was treated, and I am okay.... so trust the medics... you will be okay. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: diagnosis to chemo starting...worried

Posts.Content: It is sooooo good that you feel so positive. As I have said on another thread, there was a recent television documentary during which a doctor predicted that soon BC would be treated as a 'chronic disease' - something which could be treated repeatably giving women a normal life-span. It isn't all bad news. Strength, sister! Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: not toooo bad today

Posts.Content: I suggest you 'phone the nurses on the Macmillan help-line. They operate Monday - Friday 9am to 8pm on 0808 808 0000. They are very kind and helpful and I'm sure they will be able point you  in the right direction. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Blurred vision

Posts.Content: There are stronger pain-killers available; Tramadol, Zamadol (a slow release form of Tramadol), Fentnyl Patches,  and for nerve pain they can prescribe low dose antidepressants such as Amitriptlyne (sic). Please don't be palmed off - rattle cages lol! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Taxotere aches

Posts.Content: Hi Tricia, It sounds like the fluid that was drained off was something called a Seroma. It is fluid (yellow/clear) which is caused by the damaged tissue knitting together. (Think of the fluid you might get when you graze your knee.) It is uncomfortable and may need draining several times but it does eventually settle down. I don't know anything about the risks etc. of increased does of radiotherapy but you may get some answers by 'asking a nurse' (click on the blue type at top right of your page). Or you could ask your GP to put you in touch with a Macmillan nurse. As to the drugs - best to follow the advice of the oncologist - everyone is different and every cancer is different. Good luck in your quest for information. KateG
Posts.Title: advice for my mum, please

Posts.Content: Oh you poor love, please don't suffer in silence! Go to your GP and ask for painkillers - no don't ask DEMAND. I suffer from chronic back pain and I had to keep on at my doctor, turning up every few days as they gradually increased the strength of pills until I could get out of bed and walk around like a semi-normal person lol! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Taxotere aches

Posts.Content: I took Femara (letrozole) for nine months - for three months prior to surgery. My surgery was delayed because of other medical problems so my treatment with Femara shrank the tumour so the planned surgery was not as radical as was originally plaaned. All of these hormone treatments have side-effects but if they kick cancer's butt.... then why not? Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: letrazole

Posts.Content: Oh Louise, what a crock of sh*t but kudos to you for chasing the medical professionals to do a proper diagnosis. You keep pushing them to do their job and put you on the road to recovery. I'm sending cyber hugs too. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: 2nd recurrence in 2 years.

Posts.Content: In the past I have blamed Tamoxifen for every ache and pain and problem, including global warming lol! But seriously, there is a lot of anecdotal eveidence of joint pain connected to Tamoxifen. However, any pain should be refered to your GP - don't suffer in silence. I have problems with back-pain (unrelated to cancer) and I had to make an enormous fuss before I was taken seriously. We patients are supposed to be just that - patient! No chance! Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: TAMOXIFEN AND PAIN IN THE NECK

Posts.Content: I can't see the airline being a problem but you might have a problem with travel insurance. Even if you have insurance in place you must declare any current treatment otherwise they may invalidate the policy. You might get further information from the helpline on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on 0808 808 0000. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Easyjet plane travel - will there be a problem?

Posts.Content: It is sad but it must help that you have your children. Cuddle your babies close - you must value them. My 'babies' are now middle-aged women and sometimes I wonder if I should have had more children but what will be... will be? Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Just hit me that there will be no more babies.

Posts.Content: I agree with Dorothee - make a fuss - don't be fobbed off. It might help you to talk to one of the wonderful nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Pain after surgery

Posts.Content: Jenny, you may have a seroma which is a collection of fluid caused by scar tissue. Think of grazing your knee as a child and the clear yellow fluid that weeps from the wound - well that is the fluid which can cause a build-up of fluid under the skin which is a seroma. It is uncomfortable and can be treated - talk to your medical team. If you need further advice please contact the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on a freephone number 0808 808 0000. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Sore Breast after treatment

Posts.Content: I had back-ache and visited my GP who just prescribed pain-killers. It was only when I saw my oncologist for a routine check-up that I was taken seriously. He ordered immediaate x-ray, bone-scan and as the results looked like mets so I was then refered for an MRI and sent to a back specialist who took further blood-tests and looked at the MRI results and decided it was NOT cancer mets. BIG SIGH OF RELIEF! I hope you get the same result. It is understandable that you would worry and I agree with the others - try and get an appointment with your oncologist. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Worried about back ache

Posts.Content: I'm not sure if I replied to you personally but I want to say, we are all in this together and any support given or received is brilliant! Cary on fighting and kick cancer's butt! Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: A big thankyou

Posts.Content: A slightly different angle on the theme... a neighbour having heard the news of my diagnosis asked, "So how long have you got?". I think she needed time to order her outfit for my funeral. Annoyingly for her, I am still here after nearly seven years. The things they say!!!! KateG
Posts.Title: Most outrageous, ridiculous etc

Posts.Content: Well done, first hurdle jumped! You're right, the waiting and uncertainty are harrowing - I know I was frightend witless but once the surgery was done I was sooooo relieved. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Re: Hello folks

Posts.Content: Oh Kath! You've had a real double=dose of sh*t from the cancer-fairy! I am so sorry to hear you are both facing a fight with cancer. I had all my lymph nodes removed from under my arm (breast cancer) but I am now six years post diagnosis and am now a 'NEDDY' - no evidence of disease. I had lots of problems with fluid under my arm and had pints drained and began to feel it would never end... but it did... as it will for you...honest! Big cyber-hugs KateG
Posts.Title: Phew.

Posts.Content: You should use a water-based cream to soften your skin before and after treatment. What you MUST NOT do is use any perfumed products (soap, shower-gel, moistourisers, talcum powder) on the area to be treated because some products contain, albeit small, quantities of aluminium which reacts with the radiotherapy. Here in the UK they suggest you wash the area with a product called SIMPLE soap - I don't know if you can get it in Spain or France, but there must be an equivilent? Most people will have a pinkening of the skin and you were unlucky to have been so badly affected. The skin beneath my breast was split and burned but I was given specialist cream to treat it and it did clear up after about three weeks. Another thing to remember is that you should avoid any 'sunbathing' of the area for about six months because you will be more inclined to burn than tan. Wear factor 40 sun cream and a large floppy hat - be pale and interesting lol! You will be measured up to map the exact site they will treat and be given pin-size tattoes to help align your body correctly on the radiotherapy table. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy question

Posts.Content: I have not heard about this but you may find more information if you contact the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephoe 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: ARTemis trial

Posts.Content: I agree with samparry, treatment for BC is come on in leaps and bounds in recent years and is very treatable. I'm sure your mum will value your support through her treatment. I know when I was diagnosed I ended up reassuring my daughters who were both frantic. Once they realised I would be okay going through treatment they found it easier to cope. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: Mum just diagnosed with breast cancer, I'm recovering from womb c...

Posts.Content: BRILLIANT NEWS! Another survivor kicking cancer's butt! Hope your other treatment goes smoothly too and you stay to lend a hand to the newbies. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Today I am a cancer survivor :)

Posts.Content: I echo what has been said - be kind to yourself! I can remember being all 'gung ho!' and 'nothing is going to beat me!'... and I didn't have chemo only surgery and radio. You are (as we all have done) being 'super brave' and 'I am Superwoman!'. Slow down... take 'baby-steps', be kind to yourself. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: hi, new to the site

Posts.Content: I'm sorry I can't answer this but suggest you join another on-line community named Breast Cancer Care where you will find many patients who are having similar treatment. Best wishes, KateG
Posts.Title: porto cath ? sp

Posts.Content: I have been taking Tamoxifen for years and will (hopefully) come to the end of my five years in March. Yes there are occassional  side effects, hot flushes, night sweats but they all fade in time  - honest! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen help please

Posts.Content: I finished five and a half years on hormone suppressing drugs (1st Letrozole then Tamoxifen) in April of this year. I have not noticed any discernible difference in how I feel but to reassure you that I feel 100 times better than I did in the first few years after treatment. I don't think we realise how the treatment takes it out of us and it takes time to slowly recover. Five years ago it was a struggle to cook a meal but this summer I catered for a lunch for fifty people. It was only then that I realised how far I'd come. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: Medication after chemo and radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Sorry, I meant to mention that not all women are prescribed hormone suppressing drugs because not all breast cancer patients have a hormone positive cancer. KateG
Posts.Title: Medication after chemo and radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Oh sorry you're feeling yuk! It sounds like no-one wants to take responsibility for your problems. Do you have a dedicated Breast Care Nurse? If so do get in touch with her asap and don't be too timid - throw a wobbly, and demand attention because you should be treated with help and respect. I found the best position for comfort was to fold up a pillow or big cushion and stick it under my arm. I carried it around everywhere and used it in the car especially. I found my underarm was numb but ached at the same time which I know, on the face of it, sounds ridiculous . The ache has gone but my under-arm is still numb six years later (not a problem... just a bit weird lol) Big cyber hugs KateG.
Posts.Title: Feeling rough at minute

Posts.Content: The numbness and heavy feeling in your arm will ease with time. I had an axillary clearance four and a half years ago and struggled with the feelings for a while. You do need to do the excercises to keep mobile (I hated the physio lol) but did my stretches like a good little cancer patient. The numbness gradually recedes but there are still areas of my arm into which I could stick pins without pain... although this NOT to be reccommended lol! I do get occasional twinges, but you need to remember the surgeons cut through a lot of nerves and they need time to 're-wire'. Overall... it is a small price to pay to kick cancer's butt! Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: numbness after node removal

Posts.Content: Oh you poor thing! Perhaps some choclate Easter Eggs will help bring a smile? Best wishes KateG

Posts.Title: Hard lump under lumpectomy scar ?

Posts.Content: I can understand your concerns and it is a horrible scary time. I didn't have such radical surgery but I did have all my lymph nodes removed. I had a drain in the lymph node site for three days which should have been sufficient time but it wasn't and resulted in something called a seroma, which is a build up of fluid caused by scar tissue (a bit like the clear fluid you get when grazing a knee). It doesn't mean you will have this but it might have been good if someone had warned me of the possibility! Although physiotherapists are the last people you may want to see after (or before) you have surgery, it is wise to take their advice about excercising and stretching your arm. They usually give you a leaflet expalining all the excercises and how often and how long you should do these excercises. Another thing I wished someone had warned me about before my axillary clearance is how HEAVY my upper arm felt. I am now four years post-surgery and still there are areas of my upper arm which, because nerves are cut through during surgery, feel numb. I could stick pins into some areas and not feel a thing ..... however not to be reccommended lol! Sorry, if I sound 'moany' - I am grateful to my surgeon and to all the other medical professionals who worked to potentially save my life. Best wishes, KateG

Posts.Content: Oh dear, you are feeling p*ssed off and with good reason! You're right about men wanting to 'cherry pick' the women younger than themselves (looking for a nurse in their old age no doubt) but there ARE nice genuine men too. Have you considered 'Internet Dating' sites? My single friends say they work so it is worth a try. There are plenty of free ones like 'pleantyoffish' but the better ones are those who charge a fee. It obviously pays to be honest but perhaps hold back on the health issues until later in a relationship, after all you are only putting your toe in the water. Yes, say something like; "I am a widow aged 60. Posts.Content: Congratulations! You've jumped the hurdles and now you're 'running on the flat' (to borrow a phrase from horse-racing lol!) With Tamoxifen you can use a locally applied oestrogen cream which helps keep your lady-bits in good working order. If you want to know more about this first click on my picture, then select my blogs, then scroll back until you find one entitled 'nettles in my knickers' which also might make you smile! Posts.Content: I took Femara for about six months before changing to Tamoxifen. Perhaps you can ask your oncologist to change your prescription. I think it is worth investigating if only for your own peace of mind. Best wishes KateG

Posts.Title: starting chemotherapy........

Posts.Content: Four and a half years ago I had an axillary clearance at the same time as my lumpectomy. Before this surgery I really didn't understand what was going to happen and what would be the possible consequences. I asked my surgeon for his opinion and took his advice.Reflecting on this, with the wisdom of hindrsight, I might have opted out of this option but I trusted my surgeon and took his advice. Although I was not aware of it at the time, my surgeon was, himself, ill with prostate cancer which, I think may have coloured his opinions about how he should treat his patients.... if it is suspect... cut it out! Eighteen months after my surgery, my surgeon died so I have no way of questioning his judgement, advice, or decision. I am in contact with a group of BC patients and we compare treatments and, because of this, I have come to my own conclusion.... not one that makes me very happy... but that it would seem that all the overweight patients have had an axillary clearance. Now, this may be because the docs can not grope through tissue to feel if axillary nodes are lumpy or swollen, or it may be a 'belt and braces' approach. Best wishes KateG

Talk to your BC nurse or oncologist and I'm sure they will reassure you that this is quite normal. Best wishes KateG

Posts.Content: My EVERY sympathy - my skin broke down around 10 days after radiotherapy ended. I thought I had 'got away with it' (lol) but it snuck up and bit me because we carry on 'cooking' for some time after rads end. It WILL get better and heal (honest) and you are right to seek help from your GP, or you could go back to the hospital rads department. That is what I did and I had excellent treatment from a nurse in radiotherapy. As to the rest of your treatment, don't worry too much about delays because what they are now planning to do is simply a mopping up operation... they've shot the baddie down. Best wishes KateG

Posts.Content: Wow! It is great to hear others say "nuts to being 'brave'... there is NO choice". My husband's employers paid for private health insurance which was great for having a single room but no good for anything else. Whilst everyone else had a designated 'breast care  nurse'... the breast-care nurses avoided me like the plague! I had recurring seromas but the breast care nurses were of no help whatsoever and  would only refer me back to my surgeon. I was made to feel like some sort of social out-cast for daring to have private health care. On the other subject of partners/spouses understanding... difficult... but try and put yourself in their shoes? Possibly it is because women are the 'carers' Best wishes KateG

Saying all of that, you don't have to put up with pain so take a trip to your GP and explain you need painkilling drugs. Best wishes KateG
Posts.Title: pain still after rads

Posts.Content: Oh you poor Love, you are going through a nightmare time and you are entitled to rage against the unfairness of it all. However, I can reassure you that treatments have progressed so much in recent years and the survival rates are brilliant. Yes, treatment can be draining but it doesn't last forever so you're wise to take it one day at a time. I know you feel you are looking down a long black tunnel but you will be surprised how quickly the treatment time passes. I belong to an informal group of BC patients and we all agree that the treatment is "do-able" and we are all out of the tunnel. I'm five years post treatment and fighting fit. Keep posting here with any questions you may have and remember you can always talk to the nurses here on this site. They operate Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm on freephone 0808 808 0000. Best wishes KateG

Posts.Title: Skin care recommendations, please

Posts.Content: Have you heard about the charity "Look Good Feel Better"? It was set up to help female cancer patients and they hold sessions where they give beauty tips, show how best to use make-up, and then give you a goody bag containing lots of top of the range make-up, and perfumes. There is generally a waiting list but the sooner you put your name down the better. I was offered a place after a cancellation. It is well worth the wait and is a great boost to moral. Best wishes KateG

I'm not sure you will find anyone on this site who will have taken as long as you because the majority of members only stay active on the site whilst they are having treatment. Posts.Content: Waiting for results is its own unique form of torture an we've all been where you are now and remember how horrible is the whole 'waiting' experience. Find a book to read - if you like Romances go for a nice cosy love story, or, if you're like me find a Murder Mystery. Whatever you do - do something nice and put your worries on the back-burner.
